item.title: Kitchen Hand
item.salary: Band 1 - Commencing at $64,217 pa Categories: Early Childhood Education About the role Based at our Boorai Child and Family Centre (Ocean Grove), you will be responsible for assisting in the preparation of age-appropriate meals and snacks in accordance with current food safety legislation and nutritional guidelines. You will also maintain the kitchen environment and equipment in a safe and hygienic manner at all times. Work type: Permanent Part-Time (3 hrs per day, Monday - Friday) Classification: Band 1 $32.49 per hour Key responsibilities include: Assist with the preparation and serving of meals appropriate to a variety of age groups. Maintain the cleanliness and hygiene of the kitchen in accordance with Health and Safety Regulations Maintain communication with Centre staff and parents in relation to the individual dietary requirements of children. About you To be successful in this role, you will have knowledge of preschool children’s nutritional requirements and food safety, and the ability to assist in the preparation of age-appropriate meals for a large number of children. Essential: A current Working with Children Check Ability to identify Health and Safety issues in the work environment. Ability to assist in the preparation of nutritionally balanced and age-appropriate meals for a large number of young children incorporating meals for children with specific dietary requirements. item.title: Program Coordinator
item.salary: Band 8 - Commencing at $122,040 pa Categories: Information Technology About the role As Program Coordinator, you’ll work across teams to ensure smooth delivery of the City’s key digital transformation program, Asset and Customer Enablement (ACE) program, providing expert advice, planning, and analysis. You’ll manage resources, timelines, and budgets to keep everything aligned and on target, ensuring key outcomes are achieved. Work type: 3 year fixed-term contract Classification: Band 8, $122.040 + super Key responsibilities include: Overseeing the day-to-day operation of the program, ensuring operations are executed according to plan. Coordinate and support team efforts to ensure timely delivery of program outcomes, proactively identifying ways to keep work on track. Build strong cross-functional partnerships with project managers, stakeholders, and technical and business teams to maintain alignment and drive successful delivery. Facilitate all aspects of the program’s resources, financials, schedules, and integrated planning for effective operations; regularly tracking and reporting on performance. Monitor and track budgets, benefits, contracts, resources, and services, ensuring expenditure within allocated budgets. Manage all key administrative processes across the program, including scheduling meetings, developing meeting agendas, tracking actions, decisions and outcomes. Develop and maintain accurate documents, co-ordinate and perform various analysis, insights and presentations to track progress, inform decision making and enable effective program governance. Identify and address potential program issues & risks proactively, taking the initiative to ensure success. Maintain relationships with a diverse set of internal and external stakeholders by adapting communication content and style to meet their needs. Provide subject matter expertise and advice to leaders and other relevant stakeholders. About you To be successful in this role, you will have a tertiary qualification in Information Technology, Computer Science or Business Management in addition to professional experience in project management or project coordination. Essential Experience: Proven ability to lead and support teams, fostering a collaborative and high-performing work environment. Strong written, verbal, and negotiation skills to influence stakeholders and gain buy-in for key initiatives. Effective problem-solving and relationship-building skills, with the ability to create strong partnerships across stakeholders. Skilled in data analysis and reporting, with the ability to interpret insights and clearly communicate findings. Experienced in driving and supporting change, ensuring proactive stakeholder engagement throughout transitions. Demonstrated expertise in financial administration, including budgeting, forecasting, and contract management. Strong stakeholder engagement skills, with a track record of working collaboratively across internal teams. Preferred candidates will be required to undergo a National Police Check Check and a Working with Children’s Check as part of the recruitment process (funded by the City). If this sounds like the role for you, then click apply now! Child Safety Responsibilities We are committed to being a child-safe organisation and have zero-tolerance for child abuse. item.title: Fire Prevention Officer
item.salary: Band 5 - Commencing at $81,005 pa Categories: Local Laws, Compliance & Regulation About the role In this role, you will contribute to the efficient and effective operation of Council’s processes and responsibilities for fire hazard identification and compliance with Council’s Local Law, Country Fire Authority (CFA) Act 1958 and Fire Rescue Victoria (FRV) Act 1958. Work type: Fixed Term (3 months) – Full Time Classification: Band 5 Commencing at $40.99 per hour Key responsibilities include: Community Engagement & Compliance : Liaise with the public regarding fire prevention, respond to complaints and enquiries, and promote compliance with relevant legislation, local laws, and council policies. Fire Hazard Inspections & Enforcement : Conduct annual fire hazard inspections, oversee seasonal staff, issue notices, and prepare documentation for legal proceedings if necessary. Planning & Reporting : Support the planning and review of the Municipal Fire Management Plan and Victorian Fire Risk Register and contribute to seasonal planning and end-of-season evaluations. Training & Support : Assist with the induction and mentoring of seasonal employees and help develop efficient record-keeping systems using council software. Administrative & Legal Duties : Write reports, maintain accurate records, represent the City in court when required, and make decisions on fire prevention notices and compliance actions. About you To be successful in this role, you will have strong communication skills with the ability to liaise with members of the community in relation to problem solving and negotiation. You must be able to work within a small but highly motivated team and enjoy putting ideas and suggestions across in line with our Better Ways of Working. Essential Experience: Completion of the Municipal Fire Prevention Officer Course an advantage but not essential. Completion of Maintain Safety at Fire Incident training an advantage but not essential. A current Victorian Driver's Licence and Working with Children’s Check You will gain knowledge of Fire Management Planning and experience in emergency management. If this sounds like the role for you, then click apply now! Child Safety Responsibilities We are committed to being a child-safe organisation and have zero-tolerance for child abuse. We have specific policies, procedures, and mandatory training in place to support employees, volunteers, and contractors to achieve and adhere to these commitments. item.title: Lead Business Analyst
item.salary: SPL Categories: Information Technology About the role In this role, you’ll partner with key stakeholders, program teams, and business service owners to define, plan, and scope business and technology changes, ensuring seamless alignment between business needs and technology platforms. You’ll bring expert skills in business analysis, process design, and requirements management, collaborating across teams to drive the program’s strategic objectives and deliver lasting impact. Work type: 3 year fixed-term contract Classification: SPL Commencing at $148,599 + super Key responsibilities include: Deliver expert business analysis across multiple projects, applying best-practice frameworks to support systems and process improvements within the program. Capture, document, and manage clear functional and non-functional requirements, including well-defined acceptance criteria. Collaborate with stakeholders to translate user needs into precise, actionable user stories. Partner with process owners to analyze current workflows, uncover inefficiencies, and recommend improvements. Analyze integration needs by documenting business processes, system specifications, and data flows to guide solution design . Lead and enhance requirements management and traceability, ensuring alignment between requirements, design, development, and testing for quality and compliance. Facilitate and manage requirements workshops, fostering clear communication and collaboration to meet project and program goals. Serve as the key liaison between business leads, project managers, and system integrators to prioritize and align business needs with program objectives. About you To be successful in this role you will have a tertiary qualification in IT, Business, or similar fields with significant professional experience in a comparable organisation. Essential Experience: Significant Professional Experience in Business Analysis Demonstrated experience across large scale projects and programs in a comparable organisation. Practical experience with the use of business process methods e.g Lean, Six-Sigma. Working knowledge of Business Analysis Body of Knowledge (BABOK), Agile delivery, and Prince2 project management methodology Experience on high profile projects or programs with multiple enterprise wide integrated and inter-related systems Effective people leadership and teamwork skills to support an environment for high-functioning, productive and engaged teams to operate. Preferred candidates will be required to undergo a National Police Check and a Working With Children's Check as part of the recruitment process (funded by the City). item.salary: Band 6 - Commencing at $95,760 pa Categories: Engineering About the role In this role, you will assist, supervise, prepare and implement sustainable traffic strategies, programs and works to facilitate the efficient movement of people and product throughout having regard to economic, social and environmental values. This position will provide timely and sound advice to internal and external customers on traffic and transport related issues associated with new developments, subdivisions and projects. Work type: Permanent Full Time – Part Time will be considered. Classification: Band 6 Commencing at $95,760 pa plus super Key responsibilities include: Investigate traffic related requests and enquiries. Prepare, collect and analyse data and prepare traffic solutions to complex problems. Manage traffic related projects and work instructions, including associated budgets as required. Maintain and operate traffic management equipment and devices as required. Manage and undertake the traffic classifier program as required. Deliver an excellent customer experience in relation to matters concerning the City’s transport and traffic management, including the resolution of complex customer enquiries and concerns relating to the role. About you To be successful in this role, you will have the following: Tertiary qualification in Civil Engineering and/or relevant industry experience. Traffic management experience in urban and regional areas. Sound knowledge of relevant policy and legislation, including relevant Australian Standards and the Road Management Act 2004. Ability to set priorities and plan/organise work allocated. Current Victorian Drivers Licence. Working with Children Check (employee). Preferred candidates will be required to undergo a National Police Check as part of the recruitment process (funded by the City). If this sounds like the role for you, then click apply now! Child Safety Responsibilities We are committed to being a child-safe organisation and have zero-tolerance for child abuse. We have specific policies, procedures, and mandatory training in place to support employees, volunteers, and contractors to achieve and adhere to these commitments. item.title: Plant, Heavy Fleet Management and In Vehicle Monitoring Officer
item.salary: Band 6 - Commencing at $95,760 pa Categories: Local Laws, Compliance & Regulation, Trades & Labour About the role Play a key role in managing and optimising the City of Greater Geelong’s fleet and plant assets. In this diverse and hands-on position, you’ll support the strategic planning, procurement, and replacement of vehicles and equipment to ensure they are safe, cost-effective, and fit for purpose. You’ll assist in delivering the Ten-Year Plant Replacement Program, guide procurement activities, and drive improvements in asset utilisation, safety, and operational efficiency through effective use of In-Vehicle Management Systems (IVMS). Your work will help ensure our fleet supports essential community services and aligns with Council’s sustainability and service delivery goals. This role offers the opportunity to collaborate across departments, contribute to continuous improvement, and make a tangible impact on how we deliver services to the Geelong community. Work type: Permanent Full Time Classification: Band 6 Commencing at $95,760 pa plus super Key responsibilities include: Fleet and Asset Management – Support the effective management, utilisation, and recordkeeping of Council’s fleet and plant assets, ensuring vehicles and equipment are safe, fit for purpose, and cost-effective. Procurement and Planning – Assist in developing and implementing the Ten-Year Plant Replacement Program and coordinate fleet procurement, replacement, and disposal activities in line with Council procedures and budgets. In-Vehicle Management Systems (IVMS) – Oversee the operation, compliance, and data integrity of IVMS, analysing data to enhance safety, operational planning, and asset utilisation. Policy, Compliance and Improvement – Contribute to the development and review of fleet policies and procedures, ensuring alignment with legislation, best practice, and continuous improvement objectives. Training and Stakeholder Support – Deliver operator training and familiarisation sessions, provide subject matter advice, and build positive relationships with internal stakeholders and external agencies. Team and Service Excellence – Support a collaborative, customer-focused team culture and contribute to a commercially driven, innovative approach to fleet management and service delivery. About you You’re a skilled and organised professional with experience in fleet management, plant operations, or vehicle maintenance. You bring a practical mindset, strong stakeholder skills, and a commitment to safety and innovation. You’ll enjoy working in a collaborative team that values professionalism, continuous improvement, and service excellence. Essential Experience: Relevant qualification in Vehicle Mechanics and or significant professional experience in specialist field(s) in a comparable organisation. Good problem solving and stakeholder management skills to work effectively with diverse stakeholders to achieve task outcomes. Demonstrated experience in fleet asset procurement and disposal aligned with current best practice, including financial planning and budget management. Substantial experience administering a diverse fleet using asset and maintenance management systems. Victorian Drivers Licence Preferred candidates will be required to undergo a National Police Check as part of the recruitment process (funded by the City). If this sounds like the role for you, then click apply now! Child Safety Responsibilities We are committed to being a child-safe organisation and have zero-tolerance for child abuse. We have specific policies, procedures, and mandatory training in place to support employees, volunteers, and contractors to achieve and adhere to these commitments. item.title: Senior IT Project Manager
item.salary: SPL Categories: Information Technology About the role In this role, you will oversee every stage of the systems development life cycle, ensuring projects are delivered on time, within budget, and to the highest quality standards. Your expertise in managing resources, schedules, budgets, and stakeholders will be key to achieving our ambitious goals. Work type: 3 year fixed term contract Classification: SPL, Commencing at $ $148,599 + plus super Key responsibilities include: Lead and manage the planning, delivery and closure of ICT projects within the ACE Program. Offer guidance and support to the project team, communicate the project vision and outcomes and support the team in achieving the project outcomes in a timely manner. Provide indirect leadership across cross-functional teams, fostering collaboration, accountability, and alignment with ACE program priorities. Steer the planning and delivery of wide range of information gathering and stakeholder consultation to specify, negotiate and agree on project deliverables Support the project governance and delivery of projects using the standard tools and templates and ensure intended outcomes are identified and achieved. Identify, assess, and manage project risks, issues, dependencies, and constraints, developing mitigation strategies and escalating critical matters to the Program Manager and Sponsor as required. Prepare project review reports, dashboards, and presentations to support governance reviews, performance tracking, and benefits realization. Continuously evaluate and enhance project management processes, identifying opportunities for improvement to strengthen delivery efficiency and team performance. Effectively manage project resources, including forecasting, allocation, and oversight of budgets and costs to ensure financial accuracy and accountability. About you To be successful in this role, you will have a tertiary qualification in Information Technology, Computer Science or Business Management. In addition, you will have a relevant professional project management certification (Prince2 or equivalent). Essential Experience: Proven experience in project delivery, with a strong record of successfully managing and delivering complex business and ICT projects. In-depth knowledge of enterprise systems, including hands-on experience implementing or working with modern ERP platforms (e.g., CRM, Asset Management) or similar large-scale business systems. Exceptional communication skills, with the ability to clearly and confidently present complex information to diverse audiences, both verbally and in writing. Strong adaptability and resilience, with the ability to navigate ambiguity and manage complex or evolving situations effectively. Advanced analytical and problem-solving capabilities within ICT environments, particularly when working with challenging or high-stakes stakeholder groups. Proven stakeholder engagement skills, with the ability to build productive partnerships and influence at all organisational levels to achieve successful outcomes. Demonstrated leadership ability, fostering a collaborative, high-performing, and engaged project team environment. Comprehensive knowledge of project management methodologies, including Waterfall, Agile/Scrum, or hybrid models, coupled with a solid understanding of change management principles and practices. Preferred candidates will be required to undergo a National Police Check and a Working with Children’s Check as part of the recruitment process (funded by the City). item.title: Senior People Partner
item.salary: Band 8 - Commencing at $122,040 pa Categories: Human Resources About the role During this 12-month, fixed term contract, you will provide trusted leadership across complex industrial and employee relations matters, ensuring positive and effective workplace outcomes in fast paced environment. With a strong focus on leadership effectiveness, organisational design and strategic people and culture initiatives, you’ll play a key role in driving outcomes that align with the City’s values and long-term strategic direction. Work type: 12 month fixed-term contract Classification: Band 8, $122,040 pa plus super Key responsibilities include: Provide expert industrial relations, employee relations, and strategic people advice to stakeholders, ensuring alignment with the Business Plan, City objectives, legislation, and policy requirements. Partner strategically with Executive Directors and Senior Leaders to deliver expert guidance across all areas of people, culture, and organisational effectiveness. Offer high-level advice and solutions on complex workforce challenges, including organisational design and change, industrial and employee relations, workforce planning, performance, and talent management. Conduct in-depth research and analysis on industrial, employee relations, and broader people matters to deliver practical, evidence-based solutions that drive positive outcomes for key stakeholders. Champion innovation and continuous improvement within the department, fostering a culture that embraces best practice and delivers exceptional outcomes for both customers and the community. Monitor, report, and utilise accurate data to track work progress and improvements against plans and budgets. Implement systems, processes, and workflows to deliver results, ensuring relevant policies, governance mechanisms, and regulations are adhered to. About you To be successful in this role, you will have a tertiary qualification in relevant Human Resources/ Industrial Relations and or significant professional experience in Human Resources/ Industrial Relations in a comparable organisation. Essential Experience: In-depth knowledge of relevant legislation, policies, and best practices relating to Human Resources and Industrial Relations. Proven ability to build relationships, influence, and collaborate effectively with a diverse range of stakeholders. Demonstrated understanding and application of a contemporary Business Partnering model, supporting activities such as coaching, workforce planning, and change management. Exempary written, verbal, and presentation skills, with the ability to engage stakeholders and gain support for key initiatives. Strong problem-solving and stakeholder management skills, with a focus on fostering collaboration and productive partnerships. Experience in designing and implementing HR strategies that meet both strategic and operational organisational needs. Proven ability to work independently, analyse complex and sometimes conflicting information, and deliver effective, evidence-based solutions. Competent at managing competing priorities and achieving results in a fast-paced, politically aware, and dynamic environment. Preferred candidates will be required to undergo a National Police Check and a Working with Children's Check as part of the recruitment process (funded by the City). If this sounds like the role for you, then click apply now! Child Safety Responsibilities We are committed to being a child-safe organisation and have zero-tolerance for child abuse. Operate and maintain plant and equipment safely and effectively. Ensure all worksites comply with Council health and safety policies and traffic management requirements. item.title: Senior Heritage Officer
item.salary: Band 7 - Commencing at $106,158 pa Categories: Urban Design & Planning About the role In this role, you’ll provide expert advice on built heritage referrals from internal and external stakeholders, and strengthen the City’s relationship with State government partners. You’ll also lead the implementation of heritage studies and offer sound advice and leadership to Council on all matters relating to heritage and conservation. Work type: Permanent, part-time position. 3 days a week. Classification: Band 7, $106,158 pa plus super pro rata Key responsibilities include: Deliver timely, high-quality responses to internal and external stakeholders, ensuring built heritage needs and standards are met. Interpret and advise on legislative, regulatory, and policy requirements to guide referrals, overlays, and Council reports. Analyse proposals and offer technical heritage input into assessments and key City projects. Prepare heritage assessments and oversee external heritage consultants where required. Support the Coordinator Built Heritage in delivering the City’s Heritage Strategy and developing policies and plans that protect and celebrate Geelong’s heritage assets. Work with internal teams, consultants, community groups, and government agencies to achieve best-practice heritage outcomes. Provide trusted, specialist advice on heritage buildings and places to leaders and stakeholders across Council. Work with the Coordinator to implement the Built Heritage Unit’s annual plans and strategic goals in line with corporate priorities. Track progress and report on outcomes to ensure projects, referrals, and strategies are delivered on time, on budget, and to the highest standards. About you To be successful in this role you will have a tertiary qualification in heritage, collection management, architecture, planning or related field and significant professional experience in heritage or collection management in a comparable organisation. Essential Experience: Proven experience preparing heritage and built form policies, studies, conservation management plans, statements of significance, and referral advice. Demonstrated ability to deliver built heritage strategies, policies, or projects on time and to a high standard. Skilled at managing multiple tasks and competing priorities while maintaining quality outcomes. Strong ability to resolve issues, build partnerships, and foster cooperation across diverse stakeholders. Experience contributing to a positive, inclusive, and multidisciplinary team environment. Proven ability to work with community groups, government agencies, and other stakeholders to achieve heritage outcomes aligned with Council objectives and policies. item.title: Organisation Planning and Insights Analyst
item.salary: Band 7 - Commencing at $106,158 pa Categories: Governance & Legal About the role The Organisation Planning and Insights Analyst plays a key role in shaping how the City plans, measures, and improves its performance. This position is responsible for developing and driving the City’s corporate and service planning frameworks, organisational performance measurement and reporting processes, and continuous review programs. You will evaluate service performance and community needs through financial, operational, and benchmarking analysis to assess efficiency, effectiveness, and strategic alignment. Work type: Permanent, full-time. Classification: Band 7, $ 106158, pa plus super Key responsibilities include: Partner with teams across the organisation to lead and support the Annual Business Planning Cycle, ensuring responsibilities are clearly defined and cascaded through the Accountability Framework. Collaborate proactively with senior leaders and their teams to identify opportunities for continuous improvement, embedding robust planning practices into everyday operations. Coordinate strategic discussions and planning activities with internal and external stakeholders to ensure alignment, informed decision-making, and effective delivery of organisational goals. Drive the end-to-end delivery of service reviews, ensuring consistency, transparency, and compliance with the Local Government Act 2020 and other regulatory standards. Evaluate service performance and community needs through financial, operational, and benchmarking analysis to assess efficiency, effectiveness, and strategic alignment. Deliver actionable, evidence-based recommendations and partner with stakeholders to embed outcomes into business planning, service planning, and budgeting processes. About you To be successful in this role, you will have a tertiary qualification in Commerce or Business fields or significant professional experience in Commerce or Business fields in a comparable organisation. Essential Experience: Understanding of evaluation methodologies / frameworks. Demonstrated experience working through milestones and stage gates. Proven ability to analyse information and make judgments. Strong interpersonal skills with the ability to engage, influence, and collaborate effectively with a wide range of stakeholders. Adept at using digital tools and technology to deliver compelling, persuasive presentations. Thrives working autonomously under broad direction, consistently delivering outcomes aligned to strategic goals and KPIs. Preferred candidates will be required to undergo a National Police Check and Working with Childrens Check as part of the recruitment process (funded by the City). If this sounds like the role for you, then click apply now! Child Safety Responsibilities We are committed to being a child-safe organisation and have zero-tolerance for child abuse. We have specific policies, procedures, and mandatory training in place to support employees, volunteers, and contractors to achieve and adhere to these commitments. Please read our Child Safe Standards Management Policy . Diversity and Inclusion At the City we want a workforce that reflects the community we live in. We welcome and embrace everyone, all people with their own unique experiences, and support and encourage all our employees to do their best work, have equal access to opportunities and a just working environment. For this reason, we particularly welcome and encourage applications from First Nations people, people with diverse cultural and linguistic backgrounds, from the LGBTQIA+ community, people with disability and people of all genders, ages and diverse experience. We are the City From parks to offices, childcare centres to works depots, leisure facilities to the Wool Museum and waterfront, our team plays a vital role in shaping our vibrant and growing community. Our community counts on us to get the essentials right while looking for ways to go beyond. By listening, collaborating, and focusing on sustainability, we strive to do the basics brilliantly and create a lasting impact. If you’re ready to be part of something bigger, join us in shaping the future of Geelong. We support accessibility and encourage discussions about any adjustments or support you may need during the recruitment process. item.title: Senior Change Lead
item.salary: SPL Categories: Business Strategy & Improvement About the role In this role, you will effectively plan and manage change activities within your portfolio of work, operating to and applying a consistent approach to change management, standards of accreditation and skill across projects at the City. You will play a critical role in building and maturing the change management capability at the City. Work type: 12 month fixed-term contract. Classification: SPL 148,599 pa + super. Key responsibilities include: Lead the planning and execution of change management activities to support implementation of strategic initiatives across the organisation Develop, integrate and implement contemporary and best practice change management strategies & plans to identify and respond to change impacts, build change resilience and optimise business readiness. Work collaboratively with project teams, People & Culture team, leaders, and change champions to socialise, integrate and embed changes. Provide subject matter or expert advice to the Directorate, ELT and other leaders across the organisation. Plan, develop and implement targeted communication and engagement strategies to ensure all stakeholders are informed, understand and embrace the change. Prepare reports, briefings and presentations to support and influence stakeholders to achieve project objectives and provide successful transition for teams and individuals Lead and manage key change training deliverables including training needs analysis, training planning and the design and development of training activities in line with adult learning principles to enable the successful implementation of change initiatives. Design, implement and manage change management processes in a unionized environment with close consideration on the industrial obligations set out in the Enterprise Agreement and associated complexities. Motivate and provide strong operational leadership to the team by fostering an inclusive, customer focused and accountable culture. About you To be successful in this role, you will have a tertiary qualification in Human Resources, Commerce/Business, Organisation Psychology or a similar field and significant professional experience in a senior change management position in a comparable organisation. Essential Experience: Demonstrated leadership and people management experience. Well-developed problem solving and stakeholder management skills with the ability to build cooperation and partnerships. Demonstrated experience in developing and delivering change management, communication, and engagement strategies within large-scale and complex project/program environments. Knowledge of contemporary, best practice change management, change communication and stakeholder engagement frameworks and methodologies. Demonstrated ability to work in partnership with the business and project teams to deliver informed, tailored and strategic change and communication products Preferred candidates will be required to undergo a National Police Check and a Working with Children's Check as part of the recruitment process (funded by the City). If this sounds like the role for you, then click apply now! Child Safety Responsibilities We are committed to being a child-safe organisation and have zero-tolerance for child abuse. We have specific policies, procedures, and mandatory training in place to support employees, volunteers, and contractors to achieve and adhere to these commitments. Please read our Child Safe Standards Management Policy . Diversity and Inclusion At the City we want a workforce that reflects the community we live in. We welcome and embrace everyone, all people with their own unique experiences, and support and encourage all our employees to do their best work, have equal access to opportunities and a just working environment. For this reason, we particularly welcome and encourage applications from First Nations people, people with diverse cultural and linguistic backgrounds, from the LGBTQIA+ community, people with disability and people of all genders, ages and diverse experience. We are the City From parks to offices, childcare centres to works depots, leisure facilities to the Wool Museum and waterfront, our team plays a vital role in shaping our vibrant and growing community. Our community counts on us to get the essentials right while looking for ways to go beyond. By listening, collaborating, and focusing on sustainability, we strive to do the basics brilliantly and create a lasting impact. If you’re ready to be part of something bigger, join us in shaping the future of Geelong. We support accessibility and encourage discussions about any adjustments or support you may need during the recruitment process. item.title: Qualified Gardener
item.salary: Band 3 - Commencing at $68,775 pa Categories: Trades & Labour About the role In this role, you will carry out horticultural and maintenance tasks, operate and maintain equipment safely, and support the Parks team in delivering high-quality, customer-focused services. You will also engage with the community and ensure accurate records of work are maintained. Work type: Permanent full time Classification: Band 2 commencing at $66,631 pa plus super (unqualified). Band 3 commencing at $68,775 pa plus super (qualified). Key responsibilities include: Follow all reasonable directions given by the Team Leader and other more senior staff in accordance with operational requirements which may include, but is not limited to, weeding, mowing, propagation, spraying of appropriate insecticides, herbicides and fungicides to a regular or modified program as required. Undertake tasks including site preparation, planting, maintenance, and liaising with community groups and the public. Operate and maintain plant and equipment, which may include, but is not limited to, sprayers, hand/small ride on mowers, small tractors and related machinery, in an effective and efficient manner and in compliance with relevant laws/regulations, codes of practice and applicable directives. Work within all Council health and safety policies and procedures. Effective and efficient recording of maintenance works undertaken, time sheets, plant sheets and recorded on Councils Management Maintenance system. About you To be successful in this role, you will have a Certificate III in Horticulture / Certificate III in Parks and Gardens or similar, or a genuine passion for horticultural maintenance in the parks environment with the commitment to undertake funded training to gain your qualification. Essential Experience: Experience in a range of horticultural activities preferably in a maintenance role. Good knowledge of a range of plant material including their growing conditions and maintenance requirements and ability to further develop knowledge through research and practical observation. Extensive experience in the broad range of horticultural maintenance activities performed in the Parks environment. Ability to embrace technology and new ways of working. Current Working with Children check (employee) A current Victorian medium truck licence (desirable). Preferred candidates will be required to undergo a National Police Check and a pre-employment medical assessment as part of the recruitment process (funded by the City). If this sounds like the role for you, then click apply now! Child Safety Responsibilities We are committed to being a child-safe organisation and have zero-tolerance for child abuse. We have specific policies, procedures, and mandatory training in place to support employees, volunteers, and contractors to achieve and adhere to these commitments. Please read our Child Safe Standards Management Policy . Diversity and Inclusion At the City we want a workforce that reflects the community we live in. We welcome and embrace everyone, all people with their own unique experiences, and support and encourage all our employees to do their best work, have equal access to opportunities and a just working environment. For this reason, we particularly welcome and encourage applications from First Nations people, people with diverse cultural and linguistic backgrounds, from the LGBTQIA+ community, people with disability and people of all genders, ages and diverse experience. We are the City From parks to offices, childcare centres to works depots, leisure facilities to the Wool Museum and waterfront, our team plays a vital role in shaping our vibrant and growing community. Our community counts on us to get the essentials right while looking for ways to go beyond. By listening, collaborating, and focusing on sustainability, we strive to do the basics brilliantly and create a lasting impact. item.description: Search jobs

item.title: The Role
item.description:
Nurse Immunisers

Horsham, Australia

Reference: 6807311

Casual Engagement (open-ended application arrangements)

An opportunity for suitably qualified individuals to join the HRCC immunisation team is available.

Nurse immunisers play a crucial role in protecting our community, by delivering the National Immunisation Program.

The successful applicants will be Registered Nurses with a Nurse Immuniser qualification. Ability to work off site and a Working with Children Check is required.

For a confidential conversation, please contact Coordinator Youth & Early Yers, Louise Kelly on 5382 9522

For more information, please see attached Position Description.

Applications will be received on an open-ended basis and interviews may proceed at any time.

Applications Close: 31 Dec 2025

item.title: Current vacancies
item.description:
• Home
  • Council
  • Careers
  • Current vacancies

Current vacancies

    General Counsel

    Apply now Job no: 493460
    Work type: Permanent
    Location: Melbourne
    Categories: Compliance

    General Counsel

    Build a practical in-house legal function for our future

    Mitchell Shire is entering a defining chapter.

    40km north of Melbourne, our Shire spans Beveridge, Wallan, Kilmore, Broadford and Seymour. We’re a key growth corridor — balancing rapid residential expansion with the country character and community values that make Mitchell, Mitchell. With more than 64,000 residents today and strong growth ahead, every one of our 40+ townships has a role to play.

    We’re setting the organisation up for what’s next.

    A new structure, four new senior leadership roles, clearer accountability and faster decisions. This position — our first in-house General Counsel — brings Legal and Property together to enable timely, well-reasoned decisions, reduce external spend and protect public value. It’s strategic when required and hands-on when it counts.

    About the role

    The General Counsel is Council’s principal legal adviser.

    Reporting to the Director, Organisational Performance and working with the Senior Management Team, you’ll establish a contemporary, service-oriented legal function, lead the Property team and turn complexity into clear, actionable solutions.  

    Focus areas include property transactions, commercial agreements, procurement and probity, governance and administrative decision-making - supported by the systems and templates that help teams deliver at pace.

    Your focus is simple: help the organisation make good decisions, quickly and confidently.

    You’ll deliver:

    • Clear, plain-language advice across property, contracts, procurement, planning, governance and administrative law.
    • Drafting and negotiation of leases, licences, deeds and commercial agreements aligned to Council’s risk profile and obligations.
    • Practical te

item.title: Current vacancies
item.salary: Band 3) plus superannuation. Positions are available at both Seymour and Kilmore Leisure Centres. About you You will be energetic, passionate and fun. You work well within a team, have outstanding communication skills and enjoy dealing with the public. You take initiative and are professional in your approach. You will possess a current level 2 first aid (HLTAID003, current Employee Working with Children Check and current AUSTSWIM or similar accreditation. If you are passionate about providing exceptional customer service and value water safety, this is a great opportunity for you! Come join our team today! All applications must address the Key Selection Criteria in the position description. For enquiries, please contact Bella Carlin, Aquatic Supervisor at Bella.Carlin@Mitchellshire.vic.gov.au or 03 5734 0635. Mitchell Shire Council are a Child Safe Organisation. The successful applicant will be required to obtain a Working with Children Check, prior to commencement. Applicants will be contacted as work becomes available. Applications close at 5pm on Wednesday 31 December 2025 Position Description Advertised: 17 Jul 2023 AUS Eastern Standard Time Applications close: 31 Dec 2025 AUS Eastern Daylight Time Back to search results Apply now Refer a friend Whatsapp Facebook LinkedIn Email App Search results Position Location Closes Swim Instructor Melbourne 31 Dec 2025 Are you fun energetic, passionate and love the water? Join our team as a Swim Instructor! Current opportunities Position Location Closes Swim Instructor Melbourne 31 Dec 2025 Are you fun energetic, passionate and love the water? Join our team as a Swim Instructor! Subscribe by email Contact us Mitchell Shire Civic Centre 113 High Street Broadford VIC 3658 Phone: 03 5734 6200 mitchell@mitchellshire.vic.gov.au Planning and Building Office 4A & 4B 61 High Street Wallan VIC 3756 Meetings by appointment only Download the My Mitchell app Quicklinks Disclaimer Privacy and security Accessibility Opening Hours Monday to Friday 8.30am to 5pm © Mitchell Shire Council 2025 Acknowledgement of Traditional Custodians Mitchell Shire Council acknowledges the Taungurung and Wurundjeri Woi-wurrung people as the Traditional Owners of the lands and waterways in the area now known as Mitchell Shire. We pay our respect to their rich cultures and to Elders past, present and emerging, and other First Nations people who live, work and play in the area. Powered by Simplegov — Website by Simple
item.description:
• Home
  • Council
  • Careers
  • Current vacancies

Current vacancies

    Swim Instructor

    Apply now Job no: 493202
    Work type: Casual
    Location: Melbourne
    Categories: Leisure Services

    Swim Instructors 

    Mitchell Shire Council has embarked on Victoria’s last great story of growth.

    Located just 40 minutes from Melbourne where the city meets the country, we’re renowned for our scenic beauty that’s rich in both history and heritage.  We’re home to a mix of beautiful natural landscapes, townships and emerging communities in some of Australia’s fastest-growing suburbs.

    Come join a Local Government Organisation offering a fantastic opportunity for Community, Opportunity and Growth for the right applicant.

    This is your opportunity to join a supportive organisation in an area with rapid population growth. In 2025 Mitchell Shire is home to 64,175 residents, it is forecast to grow to 221,636 by 2046.

    About the Role

    A typical day in the role includes educating a range of age groups on water safety by the development of fun and engagement programs, supporting the provision of a safe environment for patrons, ensuring that the Aquatic Facilities operates in a clean, hygienic and safe manner in accordance with health regulations and public safety requirements. Our Leisure Centres operate seven (7) days a week with outdoor pools running through the Summer Season.

    This is a casual opportunity with the hourly rate beginning at $42.57 (LSO Band 3) plus superannuation. Positions are available at both Seymour and Kilmore Leisure Centres.

    About you

    You will be energetic, passionate and fun. You work well within a team, have outstanding communication skills and enjoy dealing with the public. You take initiative and are professional in your approach. You will possess a current level 2 first aid (HLTAID003, current Employee Working with Children Check and current AUSTSWIM or similar accreditation.

    If you are passionate about providing exceptional customer service and value water safety, this is a great oppo

item.salary: Band 8) plus superannuation. About You You’re a curious problem-solver with a knack for simplifying complexity. You know your way around TechnologyOne (Ci & Ci Anywhere) and can balance the big-picture strategy with hands-on technical detail. You’re just as comfortable deep-diving into SQL and workflows as you are explaining a solution to a non-technical stakeholder. You’ll bring: Around 10+ years of hands-on TechnologyOne configuration or consulting experience , ideally within mid-to-large, complex organisations. Deep knowledge of TechnologyOne’s core features — from user access, permissions and security categories, to ETL, stored procedures, BPAs, data models and analytics. Solid SQL and programming skills to create stored scripts, advanced queries, and data extracts that make systems talk to each other beautifully. A strong grasp of the solution design and development lifecycle — you know your way from requirements gathering and scoping through to configuration, testing, and change management. Proven project management experience , successfully delivering enterprise-level improvements and system changes. The ability to clearly document and communicate changes, ensuring transparency and continuity across teams. You’re collaborative, detail-oriented, and not afraid to roll up your sleeves to make tech work better for people.   • Council
  • Careers
  • Current vacancies

Current vacancies

    Risk and Insurance Officer

    Apply now Job no: 493455
    Work type: Permanent
    Location: Melbourne
    Categories: Governance

    Risk and Insurance Officer (Part time opportunity)

    Mitchell Shire Council has embarked on Victoria’s last great story of growth.

    Located just 40 minutes from Melbourne where the city meets the country, we’re renowned for our scenic beauty that’s rich in both history and heritage.  We’re home to a mix of beautiful natural landscapes, townships and emerging communities in some of Australia’s fastest-growing suburbs.

    Come join a Local Government Organisation offering a fantastic opportunity for Community, Opportunity and Growth for the right applicant.

    This is your opportunity to join a supportive organisation in an area with rapid population growth. In 2025 Mitchell Shire is home to 64,175 residents, it is forecast to grow to 221,636 by 2046.

    About the Opportunity

    An integral team part of the Risk team, the Risk and Insurance Officer will liaise with the community and staff to manage incidents, complaints and claims related to property, motor vehicle, public liability and professional indemnity.  You will be responsible for the timely and accurate review of community concerns and associated insurance claims which may result.  Continuous improvement in service delivery will be an outcome from investigations of incidents and the management of these in the risk system.  You will assist in the insurance renewal process and in engaging the organisation in the management of risk.  This position offers onsite and flexible working arrangements. 

    This role is a permanent, part-time opportunity (FTE 0.60 - 45.60 hours per fortnight). Remuneration begins at $91.6K to $99.6K (Band 6) pro rata plus superannuation.

    About You

    You are customer focused, with gre

item.salary: Band 5) plus superannuation. About You You’re a hands-on organiser who loves sport and community. You bring: Experience in indoor sport/recreation operations and/or program delivery. Confidence engaging clubs, schools and peak sporting bodies to grow participation. Strong customer service, scheduling and stakeholder skills. Working knowledge of OHS, Child Safe Standards and incident response. Ability to supervise casual/event staff and manage budgets, procurement and POS/booking systems. Mandatory: Working with Children Check; Provide First Aid & CPR. (Food Safety desirable for kiosk operations.) item.description:
• Home
  • Council
  • Careers
  • Current vacancies

Current vacancies

    Stadium Activation Officer

    Apply now Job no: 493468
    Work type: Permanent
    Location: Melbourne
    Categories: Leisure Services

    Stadium Activation Officer

    Mitchell Shire Council has embarked on Victoria’s last great story of growth.

    Located just 40 minutes from Melbourne where the city meets the country, we’re renowned for our scenic beauty that’s rich in both history and heritage. We’re home to a mix of beautiful natural landscapes, townships and emerging communities in some of Australia’s fastest-growing suburbs.

    Come join a Local Government Organisation offering a fantastic opportunity for Community, Opportunity and Growth for the right applicant.

    This is your opportunity to join a supportive organisation in an area with rapid population growth. In 2025 Mitchell Shire is home to 64,175 residents; it is forecast to grow to 221,636 by 2046.

    About the Opportunity

    Help us turn two under-utilised stadiums into buzzing community hubs. On a typical day you’ll:

    • Lead smooth stadium operations at Seymour Sports & Aquatic Centre Stadium and Broadford Leisure Centre Stadium (presentation, cleaning, kiosk, customer service and OHS).

    • Coordinate casual rosters for peak times and events, and manage bookings, allocations and invoicing in line with Council’s User Fees and Charges.

    • Build programs for all ages and abilities across multiple indoor sports, partnering with peak sporting bodies to bring clinics, comps and coach/official development to Mitchell.

    • Engage clubs and schools, support governance and scheduling, and help activate regular after-school opening at Broadford for casual shooting, youth engagement and future health and fitness options.

    Hours: While not currently set hours, a large proportion of this role will be after-school, direct service hours at the Broadford Leisure Centre (Stadium) to support site opening. You may also n

Current vacancies

    Information Services Officer

    Apply now Job no: 493463
    Work type: Permanent
    Location: Melbourne
    Categories: Governance

    Information Services Officer

    Mitchell Shire Council has embarked on Victoria’s last great story of growth.

    Located just 40 minutes from Melbourne where the city meets the country, we’re renowned for our scenic beauty that’s rich in both history and heritage.  We’re home to a mix of beautiful natural landscapes, townships and emerging communities in some of Australia’s fastest-growing suburbs.

    Come join a Local Government Organisation offering a fantastic opportunity for Community, Opportunity and Growth for the right applicant.

    This is your opportunity to join a supportive organisation in an area with rapid population growth. In 2025 Mitchell Shire is home to 64,175 residents, it is forecast to grow to 221,636 by 2046.

    About the Opportunity

    If you have a passion for records management and have a good eye for detail this role is for you. The Information Services Unit is a customer focused unit providing information management services to Council.

    This role is a permanent, full-time opportunity with a Monthly ADO. Remuneration begins at $76.4K to $87.1K (Band 5) plus superannuation.

    About You

    The successful applicant will help keep our operations running smoothly every day. Working alongside the Senior Information Services Officer, you’ll handle incoming correspondence (both digital and hardcopy), retrieve and cross-reference files, and play a key role in maintaining our Electronic Document Management System.

    If you’re someone who enjoys reading, takes pride in accuracy, and likes seeing how the small details make a big difference, this is the perfect role to put your skills into action and make a real impact!

    For further information about this role please contact Jennifer Moore, Senior Information Services Officer on 03 5734 6498.

item.salary: Band 7) plus superannuation. About You We are looking for someone with experience and qualifications in open space planning, environment planning, landscape architecture or related fields. You will be a critical cog in the process of Precinct Structure Plans, Development Plans and Statutory Planning referrals and advocating for, and understanding the importance of open space will be front of mind. Working in a diverse environment comprising of greenfields sites through to established townships - and everything in between you will be flexible, knowledgable, self motivated and keen to make a difference to the lives of our ever growing community. For further information about this role please contact Dean Frank, Recreation and Open Space Coordinator, on 03 5734 6374. All applications must address the Key Selection Criteria in the position description. For information on how to apply, please visit our Careers page .   • Council

  • Current vacancies

Current vacancies

    Open Space Planner

    Apply now Job no: 493469
    Work type: Permanent
    Location: Melbourne
    Categories: Community Services and Development, Planning

    Open Space Planner

    Mitchell Shire Council has embarked on Victoria’s last great story of growth.

    Located just 40 minutes from Melbourne where the city meets the country, we’re renowned for our scenic beauty that’s rich in both history and heritage.  We’re home to a mix of beautiful natural landscapes, townships and emerging communities in some of Australia’s fastest-growing suburbs.

    Come join a Local Government Organisation offering a fantastic opportunity for Community, Opportunity and Growth for the right applicant.

    This is your opportunity to join a supportive organisation in an area with rapid population growth. In 2025 Mitchell Shire is home to 64,175 residents, it is forecast to grow to 221,636 by 2046.

    About the Opportunity

    The Open Space Planner role will lead the development and implementation of policies, strategies, and plans that guide the delivery of open space services across the municipality, including the finalisation and implementation of the Mitchell Open Space Strategy.
     
    This position will ensure that the planning and provision of open space meet the needs of Mitchell’s current and future communities, supporting sustainable growth and enhancing the overall liveability of the region.
     
    The role will also be responsible for building and maintaining strong, effective partnerships with key stakeholders, including internal departments, government agencies, and community organisations. Through these collaborations, the Open Space Planner will facilitate the achievement of Council’s strategic goals and priorities, working to improve recreation and open space outcomes and contribute to the health and wellbeing of Mitchell’s communities.

    This role is a permanent opportunity with a Monthly ADO. Remuneration begins at $102.7K to $114.7K (Band 7) plus superannuat

• Home
  • Council
  • Careers
  • Current vacancies

Current vacancies

    Debt Collection Officer

    Apply now Job no: 493470
    Work type: Permanent
    Location: Melbourne
    Categories: Finance

    Debt Collection Officer

    Mitchell Shire Council has embarked on Victoria’s last great story of growth.

    Located just 40 minutes from Melbourne where the city meets the country, we’re renowned for our scenic beauty that’s rich in both history and heritage.  We’re home to a mix of beautiful natural landscapes, townships and emerging communities in some of Australia’s fastest-growing suburbs.

    Come join a Local Government Organisation offering a fantastic opportunity for Community, Opportunity and Growth for the right applicant.

    This is your opportunity to join a supportive organisation in an area with rapid population growth. In 2025 Mitchell Shire is home to 64,175 residents, it is forecast to grow to 221,636 by 2046.

    About the Opportunity

    We're looking for a proactive and detail-oriented Debt Collection Officer to join our Revenue Team. The role will be responsible for ensuring the timely and efficient delivery of debt recovery processes across Council's revenue streams - from rates and charges to sundry debts. You'll engage directly with residents, businesses, and internal stakeholders to resolve outstanding accounts respectfully and effectively.

    This role is a permanent, part-time (0.6 FTE, 45.60 hours per fortnight) opportunity. Remuneration begins at $76.4K to $87.1K (Band 5) pro-rata for part time, plus superannuation.

    About You

    You will have experience with debt collection and revenue management with strong communication and negotiation skills and posses a sound understanding of relevant legislation, policies and debt recovery practices. You'll need a high attention to detail and bring with you a positive attitude and commitment to supporting the community.

    For further information about this role please contact Brocke Gallagher, Revenue Coordinator on 03 5734 6200.

    All applications must address the Key

item.title: Working at Northern Grampians Shire Council
item.description:
<!DOCTYPE html> <!--[if lt IE 7]> <html class="no-js lt-ie9 lt-ie8 lt-ie7" lang="en"> <![endif]--><!--[if IE 7]> <html class="no-js lt-ie9 lt-ie8" lang="en"> <![endif]--><!--[if IE 8]> <html class="no-js lt-ie9" lang="en"> <![endif]--><!--[if gt IE 8]><!--><html class="no-js" lang="en-AU"> <!--<![endif]--> <head> <!-- Published by OpenCities, 1.36.1.2 --> <meta charset="utf-8"/> <meta content="IE=edge,chrome=1" http-equiv="X-UA-Compatible"/> <meta content="#233549" name="theme-color"/> <title>Working at Northern Grampians Shire Council </title> <meta content="OpenCities - https://granicus.com/product/opencities" name="generator"/> <meta content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0" name="viewport"/> <meta content="yes" name="apple-mobile-web-app-capable"/> <meta content="Find out what it is like to work at the Northern Grampians Shire Council. item.title: Child and Family Support Assistant
item.salary: Band 4 salary from $78,402.48 per annum plus superannuation and a fortnightly RDO Location: Werribee based with potential for a hybrid work arrangement About the role This is an exciting time to be a part of Wyndham’s early years services! With over 100 babies born every week in the municipality and over 6,000 registrations received yearly via our kindergarten central registration system, Wyndham is a growing community that looks for open-minded, passionate, and community-focused people to respond to their needs. In the Child & Family Support Team, you are integral to the success of the Community Support Department by delivering high-quality customer service and administration skills to facilitate access to Maternal & Child Health services and the kindergarten Central Registration Scheme for the community. This rewarding role will require you to be able to address the needs of our community in an efficient and effective manner, maintaining compliance with our regulatory and operational requirements and procedures. Never a dull moment in this role, you will thrive with your attention to detail, positive stakeholder collaboration, and exceptional customer service skills. We are seeking Child & Family Support Assistants to join our team supporting the delivery of Maternal & Child Health services in a temporary capacity or the kindergarten Central Registration Scheme in a permanent capacity, ensuring that Wyndham is meeting the growing demand for these services. Within the Maternal & Child Health stream, your day-to-day will see you processing notifications of new births in Wyndham, responding to nurse requests, maintaining the appointment calendars, and, crucially, supporting customer access to the service. Previous experience in MCH, health, early years services, or a similar, highly-regulated environment is desirable. Within the kindergarten central registration stream, your day-to-day will involve administering the Central Registration Scheme. You will be responsible for processing registration applications into the central registration system, empowering families to navigate and access kindergarten services, and responding to a variety of complex customer queries. Previous experience in early years services or central registration is desirable. What your day will look like Providing friendly, professional, and helpful assistance to community members, supporting them to access early years and family services that meet their needs. Delivering accurate and efficient administrative support to the Community Support Department, contributing to the smooth operation of all children and family services. Processing registrations, bookings, and birth notifications in line with council policies, procedures, and regulatory requirements. Liaising with internal teams and external partners about registrations, referrals, bookings, and system updates to ensure accurate information sharing and service delivery. Maintaining accurate records, data entry, and statistical reporting using council databases and reporting systems. Supporting continuous improvement by assisting with general administrative tasks and other duties aligned with your skills, abilities, and the needs of the team. What you will bring Demonstrated ability to work within a team environment collaboratively and respectfully, striving towards Council’s values, policies, and procedures Strong administrative experience, with proficiency in a range of computer systems and the ability to learn other software programs High-level customer service and problem-resolution skills to support community and stakeholders in a dynamic, fast-paced environment The ability to organise and control one's own workload and time to achieve specified outputs Certificate in administration or relevant administration experience Current Working with Children Check or willingness to obtain one If you progress past the interview stage, you may be required to complete pre-employment screening, which may include police checks, a medical, qualification verification, and an Australian work rights check. Why join Wyndham We are one of Australia’s fastest growing and most diverse cities. By 2040, we will have more than 500,000 residents and our people are hard at work designing the precincts, building the infrastructure, developing the policies and delivering the programs that will ensure the City is prepared. Look at our job opportunities and you may be surprised at what you discover: a future-focused culture, a sense of purpose and possibility, and real opportunities to strengthen our diverse community. It all adds up to make Wyndham City a great place to belong. Our people are our most valued asset. We are focused on building a culture that empowers every person to do their best work. Flexibility is built right into our DNA and we are committed to cultivating an inclusive workplace that celebrates a diverse workforce. How to apply Please apply online by submitting your resume and cover letter outlining your suitability for the role via the provided link. Applications close at 11:59PM on Sunday, 2 November 2025. If you have further role-specific questions, please contact Kaycee Shapter, Team Leader Child & Family Support on 9394 6885. Wyndham City Council is committed to providing a recruitment experience that is fair, inclusive, and accessible. If you have specific accessibility needs or general recruitment enquiries, please contact our Careers team via careers@wyndham.vic.gov.au or 03 9394 6860. Child Safe Organisation Wyndham City Council has zero tolerance to any form of child abuse and is committed to the safety, wellbeing and empowerment of children. We create and maintain a child safe organisation which is embedded in the everyday thinking and practice of all employees, volunteers and contractors. Additionally, we are committed to fostering a culture of safety within the Council, which includes the inclusion and empowerment of Aboriginal children, their families, and communities. Our recruitment practices reflect this. Diversity and Inclusion At Wyndham City Council we value workforce diversity and inclusion and embrace individual uniqueness. We value diverse life experiences and the perspectives of our people, while providing high-quality services to all members of our community, regardless of age, gender, ethnicity, religion, cultural background, disability, or sexuality. Wyndham has one of the largest Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities in the Western Region, with a rich and diverse history. We are committed to providing positive employment opportunities for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and welcome applications from candidates of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander background. To read more about Wyndham City’s Innovate Reconciliation Action Plan, please visit our website . Additional Information Employee Status: Permanent Schedule: Full-time Position Description: PD Current - City Life - Community Support - Child and Family Support Assistant - Various x 22 - Band 4 Previous Searches My Profile Create and manage profiles for future opportunities. With over 100 babies born every week in the municipality, Wyndham is a growing community that looks for open-minded, passionate, and community-focused people to respond to their needs. Within the team, your day-to-day will see you processing notifications of new births in Wyndham, responding to nurse requests, maintaining the appointment calendars, and, crucially, supporting customer access to the service. It all adds up to make Wyndham City a great place to belong. Our people are our most valued asset. We are focused on building a culture that empowers every person to do their best work. Flexibility is built right into our DNA and we are committed to cultivating an inclusive workplace that celebrates a diverse workforce. item.title: Area Leader Capital Delivery
item.salary: Band 8 salary from $132,607.76 per annum plus superannuation and a fortnightly RDO Location: Werribee based About the role We have two key opportunities, reporting to the Coordinator Construction and Development Services, for an Area Leader (Brownfields) and Area Leader (Greenfields). These roles are responsible for leading the operational delivery of Council’s capital works program, with a strong emphasis on building projects across both established (Brownfields) and growth (Greenfields) areas. Each Area Leader will provide strategic and day-to-day leadership, coordination, and professional support to a team of Senior Project Managers and Project Managers, ensuring the successful planning, design, procurement, and delivery of high-quality community infrastructure. You will ensure infrastructure and facilities projects are delivered on time, on budget, and to the highest quality and compliance standards while fostering a high-performance, collaborative team culture. This role also supports resource management, program-level oversight, risk management, financial accountability, and long-term infrastructure investment planning. Working within the Construction and Development Services Unit in the Facilities, Fleet & Depot Stores Department of the City Operations Directorate, you will be instrumental in driving continuous improvement in project management capability, stakeholder engagement, and service delivery for the community. This position may require occasional weekend, public holiday, and after-hours work, as well as travel across the municipality. What your day will look like · Lead, mentor, and supervise Senior Project Managers and Project Managers to ensure effective delivery of capital works projects · Oversee operational leadership across capital works programs, including project milestones, resource planning, and reporting · Ensure compliance with codes, scope, budget, time, and quality standards, escalating issues where necessary · Manage financial activities including budget preparation, forecasting, and cost control · Oversee preparation and quality control of project documentation from design to delivery including contracts, tenders, and contractor performance reports · Promote strong stakeholder engagement and communication to minimise disruptions and maximise community benefit · Drive continuous improvement in project management systems, processes, and governance What you will bring · Tertiary qualification in Project Management, Civil/Structural Engineering, Construction Management, Architecture, or a related discipline · Extensive experience delivering complex infrastructure projects, with a focus on facilities greenfield or brownfield delivery, in a public sector, consulting, or construction environment · Proven leadership skills in managing and developing multidisciplinary project teams · Strong financial, contract administration, risk management, and WHS compliance knowledge · High-level proficiency in project management systems · Excellent stakeholder engagement, negotiation, and communication skills · Understanding of long-term asset planning and infrastructure investment strategies · Current Victorian Driver’s Licence, Construction Induction (White) Card, and Working with Children Check If you progress past the interview stage, you may be required to complete pre-employment screening, which may include police checks, a medical, qualification verification, and an Australian work rights check. Why join Wyndham We are one of Australia’s fastest growing and most diverse cities. By 2040, we will have more than 500,000 residents and our people are hard at work designing the precincts, building the infrastructure, developing the policies and delivering the programs that will ensure the City is prepared. Look at our job opportunities and you may be surprised at what you discover: a future-focused culture, a sense of purpose and possibility, and real opportunities to strengthen our diverse community. It all adds up to make Wyndham City a great place to belong. Our people are our most valued asset. We are focused on building a culture that empowers every person to do their best work. Flexibility is built right into our DNA and we are committed to cultivating an inclusive workplace that celebrates a diverse workforce. How to apply Please apply online by submitting your resume and cover letter outlining your suitability for the role via the provided link. Applications close at 11:59PM on Sunday, 9 November 2025. If you have further role-specific questions, please contact Amol Khapre, Coordinator Construction & Development Services on 9394 6881. Wyndham City Council is committed to providing a recruitment experience that is fair, inclusive, and accessible. If you have specific accessibility needs or general recruitment enquiries, please contact our Careers team via careers@wyndham.vic.gov.au or 03 9394 6860. Child Safe Organisation Wyndham City Council has zero tolerance to any form of child abuse and is committed to the safety, wellbeing and empowerment of children. We create and maintain a child safe organisation which is embedded in the everyday thinking and practice of all employees, volunteers and contractors. Additionally, we are committed to fostering a culture of safety within the Council, which includes the inclusion and empowerment of Aboriginal children, their families, and communities. Our recruitment practices reflect this. Diversity and Inclusion At Wyndham City Council we value workforce diversity and inclusion and embrace individual uniqueness. item.title: Senior Fleet Officer
item.salary: Band 6 salary from $104,133.36 per annum plus superannuation and a fortnightly RDO Location: Werribee and Hoppers Crossing based About the role As a Senior Fleet Officer, you will partner with Team Leader Fleet Management to deliver a fully integrated approach to fleet procurement, lifecycle maintenance, and policy compliance. You will make this role your own driving the specialist data, systems, and procurement functions that keep Council’s fleet safe, cost-efficient, and compliant to audits while looking for improvements along the way. What your day will look like · Managing the yearly Fleet Procurement Plan, including light vehicles, trucks, specialised fleet items and plant, using proven assessment methods of assets due for changeover and make recommendations on appropriate replacements · Developing vehicle and plant specifications with relevant stakeholders ensuring alignment with operational needs and Council policy · Leading the procurement process including preparation of Tender and RFQ documentation · Maintaining the accuracy of Fleet data in Council’s long-term financial place and asset plan, and assets plan · Administering the roadside assistance programs, fuel cards, registration renewal and toll invoice processing · Administering Council’s GPS platform, including data accuracy user access and vendor liaison · Overseeing the pool-vehicle booking system, ensuring availability, utilisation reporting and user support · Analysing fleet lifecycle cost, utilisation, and data, and support implementation of data-informed approaches to optimise Fleet What you will bring · Degree or diploma in a relevant field with relevant experience OR a lesser qualification with substantial relevant experience in procurement · Well-developed interpersonal and communication skills both verbal and written, with the ability to deal with a diverse range of stakeholders · Well-developed time management and organisational skills with the ability to work autonomously · Demonstrated ability to apply critical thinking, creative problem solving and the ability to make professional and complex judgements · Experience managing or contributing to long-term fleet planning and lifecycle optimisation is highly desirable If you progress past the interview stage, you may be required to complete pre-employment screening, which may include police checks, a medical, qualification verification, and an Australian work rights check. Why join Wyndham We are one of Australia’s fastest growing and most diverse cities. By 2040, we will have more than 500,000 residents and our people are hard at work designing the precincts, building the infrastructure, developing the policies and delivering the programs that will ensure the City is prepared. Flexibility is built right into our DNA and we are committed to cultivating an inclusive workplace that celebrates a diverse workforce. Wyndham City Council is committed to providing a recruitment experience that is fair, inclusive, and accessible.
