item.title: Principal Open Space Planner
item.salary: Band 7 salary from $115,575.61 per annum plus superannuation and a fortnightly RDO Location: Werribee based About the role Join Wyndham’s City Operations Directorate to lead open space policy, including the implementation and update of Wyndham’s Open Space Strategy. You will work alongside a community focused team to develop and implement Open Space policies, strategies and plans, and provide open space planning and urban design advice, to achieve integrated planning and design outcomes which result in consistent, high-quality design and functional open space outcomes across the City. What your day will look like · Provide specialist strategic open space planning and urban design advice on planning permit applications, precinct structure plans, development contribution plans, structure plans, urban design frameworks, master plans, activity centre plans and other planning and development proposals · Develop strategies, policies and plans to guide the planning, development, and management of the City’s open space network · Engage with the Wyndham Community on open space planning issues, requests, and for strategy and policy development · Provide specialist open space planning and urban design advice into projects and initiatives across Council, including externally led projects, to ensure integrated planning and design outcomes are achieved · Prepare reports, submissions, briefing papers, and project update reports for senior management, executive and Council What you will bring · Tertiary qualifications in Open Space Planning, Urban Design, Landscape Architecture, Recreation Planning, Town Planning, Strategic Planning or a related field · Extensive, practical experience in open space planning resulting in a sound knowledge of standards of open space provision within Local Government, particularly in growth areas · A comprehensive knowledge of research, planning methods and urban planning schemes and principles · Extensive, practical experience in policy and report writing · Well-developed communication and collaboration skills · Highly developed analytical, conceptual, dispute resolution and negotiation skills and abilities · Extensive experience in community consultation and working with community groups in the delivery of projects which meet community and Council expectations · Well-developed time management and organisational skills If you progress past the interview stage, you may be required to complete pre-employment screening, which may include police checks, a medical, qualification verification, and an Australian work rights check. Why join Wyndham We are one of Australia’s fastest growing and most diverse cities. By 2040, we will have more than 500,000 residents and our people are hard at work designing the precincts, building the infrastructure, developing the policies and delivering the programs that will ensure the City is prepared. Look at our job opportunities and you may be surprised at what you discover: a future-focused culture, a sense of purpose and possibility, and real opportunities to strengthen our diverse community. It all adds up to make Wyndham City a great place to belong. Our people are our most valued asset. We are focused on building a culture that empowers every person to do their best work. Flexibility is built right into our DNA and we are committed to cultivating an inclusive workplace that celebrates a diverse workforce. How to apply Please apply online by submitting your resume and a cover letter which outlines your suitability for the role and responds to the key selection criteria outlined in the position description, via the provided link. Applications close at 11:59PM on Sunday, 9th November 2025. If you have further role-specific questions, please contact Bridê Blake, Team Leader Open Space Planning on 03 8734 2640 or email Bride.Blake@wyndham.vic.gov.au Wyndham City Council is committed to providing a recruitment experience that is fair, inclusive, and accessible. If you have specific accessibility needs or general recruitment enquiries, please contact our Careers team via careers@wyndham.vic.gov.au or 03 9394 6860. item.title: Cleansing Litter Garbage & Sanitary
item.salary: Band 2 salary from $73,668.75 per annum plus superannuation and a fortnightly RDO Location: Hoppers Crossing based About the role This role forms part of the Assets and Roads cleansing workforce carrying out allocated tasks to specified standards and schedules in order to meet agreed productivity and quality standards. The successful candidate will be predominantly placed within the Garbage team, however at times will be required to assist in other cleansing teams. The team is looking for an energetic person to assist in keeping Wyndham clean. Ideally, you are someone who enjoys working in growing community to keep Open Space reserves clean and tidy. What your day will look like · Providing a rapid response service as required · Being responsible for the care of plant, tools and equipment, and to fulfill daily allocated tasks. Report any observed road maintenance issues (e.g. potholes, missing pit lids, apply absorbent to spills etc.) · Providing traffic control for other crews as required · Monitoring and reporting items of vehicular maintenance · Performing daily maintenance of vehicle and plant What you will bring · Ability to plan and fulfill daily allocated tasks · A current Victorian Drivers licence including Truck licence (up to 13.9T) · Demonstrated competency in the use of small plant and truck mounted crane · Ability to understand and work to a schedule and plans · Experience in cleansing or other outdoor maintenance works · Demonstrated understanding of OH&S including manual handling and the need to ensure good posture and precautions when working · Sound interpersonal and communication skills both verbal and written If you progress past the interview stage, you may be required to complete pre-employment screening, which may include police checks, a medical, qualification verification, and an Australian work rights check. Why join Wyndham We are one of Australia’s fastest growing and most diverse cities. By 2040, we will have more than 500,000 residents and our people are hard at work designing the precincts, building the infrastructure, developing the policies and delivering the programs that will ensure the City is prepared. item.title: Customer Service Officer (Talent Pool)
item.salary: Band 4 salary of $78,402.48 per annum plus superannuation and a fortnightly RDO Location: Werribee Based IMPORTANT: This recruitment process is not for an immediate vacancy, but to establish a Talent Pool for future Ongoing or Temporary roles that may arise over the next six months. About the role This role will see you support the Community First Team functions relating to contact centre operations. Phone calls from residents will make up a big part of your day, with the prospect of face-to face interactions once fully trained. You’ll contribute to the great culture in a team of 30 plus agents, servicing the community of Wyndham. To set you up for success, you will be initially working in the office for training and support, with the possibility of a hybrid workweek in the future. What your day will look like · You’ll personally handle or redirect enquiries for over 100+ council services, in an efficient, courteous and professional manner · Provide excellent customer support to the community and staff across all customer channels; phone being the initial starting point · Meet service levels and standards, a focus on customer satisfaction and industry best practice within Council’s policies · Utilise Councils reporting system to record the nature and type of customer enquiries to ensure a successful outcome for the customer What you will bring · Experience in a similar fast-paced customer service role · A natural love of the buzz of a call centre and helping people · A personality that enjoys building relationships with the community · Competence with using a computer and different database programs · A mindset that puts customers at the centre of what you do · A continuous improvement mindset with a positive, proactive, and flexible attitude If you progress past the interview stage, you may be required to complete pre-employment screening, which may include police checks, a medical, qualification verification, and an Australian work rights check. Why join Wyndham We are one of Australia’s fastest growing and most diverse cities. By 2040, we will have more than 500,000 residents and our people are hard at work designing the precincts, building the infrastructure, developing the policies and delivering the programs that will ensure the City is prepared. Look at our job opportunities and you may be surprised at what you discover: a future-focused culture, a sense of purpose and possibility, and real opportunities to strengthen our diverse community. It all adds up to make Wyndham City a great place to belong. Our people are our most valued asset. We are focused on building a culture that empowers every person to do their best work. Flexibility is built right into our DNA and we are committed to cultivating an inclusive workplace that celebrates a diverse workforce. How to apply Please apply online by submitting your resume and cover letter outlining your suitability for the role via the provided link. Applicants may be contacted as opportunities arise if they are considered suitable. Due to the ongoing nature of this recruitment process, communication of an outcome for your application may be delayed. Applications close at 11:59PM on Sunday 9 November 2025. If you have further role-specific questions, please contact Jodie Hatfield or Jonothan Woodforde, Team Leaders Customer Service on 1300 023 411. Wyndham City Council is committed to providing a recruitment experience that is fair, inclusive, and accessible. If you have specific accessibility needs or general recruitment enquiries, please contact our Careers team via careers@wyndham.vic.gov.au or 03 9394 6860. Child Safe Organisation Wyndham City Council has zero tolerance to any form of child abuse and is committed to the safety, wellbeing and empowerment of children. We create and maintain a child safe organisation which is embedded in the everyday thinking and practice of all employees, volunteers and contractors. Additionally, we are committed to fostering a culture of safety within the Council, which includes the inclusion and empowerment of Aboriginal children, their families, and communities. Our recruitment practices reflect this. Diversity and Inclusion At Wyndham City Council we value workforce diversity and inclusion and embrace individual uniqueness. We value diverse life experiences and the perspectives of our people, while providing high-quality services to all members of our community, regardless of age, gender, ethnicity, religion, cultural background, disability, or sexuality. Wyndham has one of the largest Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities in the Western Region, with a rich and diverse history. We are committed to providing positive employment opportunities for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and welcome applications from candidates of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander background. To read more about Wyndham City’s Innovate Reconciliation Action Plan, please visit our website . item.title: Senior Project Engineer
item.salary: Band 8 salary from $132,607.76 per annum plus superannuation and a fortnightly RDO Location: Werribee based About the role As a Senior Project Engineer within our Roads and Maintenance department, you will take advantage of your sound knowledge of engineering design standards and guidelines, construction principles, project management, contract management and stakeholder engagement to provide specialist technical and engineering support to your unit and other departments. You will effectively manage and coordinate the programming and delivery of major and complex road projects including management of design consultants, subcontractors and stakeholders related to the capital works program and achieve best practice in the provision of infrastructure. As you will be providing direct supervision of the engineering work of unregistered engineers within the unit in accordance with the Professional Engineers Registration Act 2019, you yourself will be required to hold a tertiary qualification in Civil Engineering and a Professional Engineers Registration. What your day will look like · Planning, designing and managing the delivery of major and complex capital works projects across the municipality · Reviewing engineering designs, cost estimates, consultant contracts and tender documentation to ensure quality and compliance · Developing and monitoring project programs, budgets, risk assessments and quality assurance systems to keep projects on track · Work closely with external consultants providing direction, oversight and support to achieve successful outcomes · Coordinating tender assessment panels and ensuring transparent, fair procurement processes · Preparing reports, briefings and presentations for senior management and Council regarding all aspects of the project delivery · Liaising with the public, service authorities, statutory agencies and other stakeholders to communicate project updates and resolve issues collaboratively · Providing guidance, mentoring and technical advice to staff in the planning and delivery of capital works projects What you will bring · Tertiary qualification in Civil Engineering with several years of subsequent relevant experience · Extensive experience in project management of highly complex road projects including budgeting, design, delivery and stakeholder management · Professional Engineers Registration in compliance with the Professional Engineers Registration Act 2019 · Experience in civil road and drainage design, traffic engineering and construction practices · Experience in contract administration and management · Highly developed organisational and project management skills with the ability to work under conflicting pressures and achieve agreed outcomes · Well-developed and demonstrated experience in conflict resolution and problem-solving skills · Knowledge and experience in AutoCAD and 12D for the design of civil road works (desirable) · Previous experience within a Government environment (desirable) If you progress past the interview stage, you may be required to complete pre-employment screening, which may include police checks, a medical, qualification verification, and an Australian work rights check. Why join Wyndham We are one of Australia’s fastest growing and most diverse cities. By 2040, we will have more than 500,000 residents and our people are hard at work designing the precincts, building the infrastructure, developing the policies and delivering the programs that will ensure the City is prepared. Look at our job opportunities and you may be surprised at what you discover: a future-focused culture, a sense of purpose and possibility, and real opportunities to strengthen our diverse community. It all adds up to make Wyndham City a great place to belong. Our people are our most valued asset. We are focused on building a culture that empowers every person to do their best work. Flexibility is built right into our DNA and we are committed to cultivating an inclusive workplace that celebrates a diverse workforce. How to apply Please apply online by submitting your resume and cover letter outlining your suitability for the role via the provided link. Applications close at 11:59PM on Sunday 9 November 2025. If you have further role-specific questions, please contact Vince Demaria, Coordinator Engineering Design on 9742 0875. Wyndham City Council is committed to providing a recruitment experience that is fair, inclusive, and accessible. If you have specific accessibility needs or general recruitment enquiries, please contact our Careers team via careers@wyndham.vic.gov.au or 03 9394 6860. Child Safe Organisation Wyndham City Council has zero tolerance to any form of child abuse and is committed to the safety, wellbeing and empowerment of children. We create and maintain a child safe organisation which is embedded in the everyday thinking and practice of all employees, volunteers and contractors. Additionally, we are committed to fostering a culture of safety within the Council, which includes the inclusion and empowerment of Aboriginal children, their families, and communities. Our recruitment practices reflect this. Diversity and Inclusion At Wyndham City Council we value workforce diversity and inclusion and embrace individual uniqueness. item.title: Senior Change Officer
item.salary: Band 7 salary from $115,575.61 per annum plus superannuation and a fortnightly RDO Location: Werribee based About the role Wyndham City’s Facilities, Fleet & Depot Stores Department keeps Council running – maintaining our diverse portfolio of buildings, managing our fleet of vehicles, and ensuring the seamless flow of essential materials, consumables that enable our community outcomes. This exciting opportunity has arisen due to the extended leave of the current officer, offering the chance to contribute to a department undergoing significant transformation and improvement. As our Senior Change Officer, you’ll play a pivotal role in shaping the next chapter of this department’s transformation. Working directly with the Manager, Facilities, Fleet & Depot Stores, you’ll design, facilitate, and lead initiatives that strengthen how we work, uplifting capability, improving culture and processes, and embedding sustainable change that supports Council’s strategic direction. This role is for someone who thrives on collaboration, innovation, and seeing ideas come to life. You’ll bring structure to complexity, turn plans into action, and help our people perform at their best as we deliver essential services to the Wyndham community. What your day will look like · Partnering with leaders and teams to co-design initiatives that deliver meaningful and measurable results. · Developing, facilitating, and at times leading implementation of change management strategies for key organisational projects. · Engaging with teams across the department to provide communication, coaching, and on-the-ground support for change adoption. · Conducting impact assessments, identifying stakeholder needs, and supporting readiness for change. · Working with stakeholders to design and deliver training that builds lasting capability. · Supporting project teams to integrate change management into project delivery, ensuring benefits are realised and sustained. · Applying best practice project management and acting as project owner or representative on key initiatives. · Translating strategic direction into practical action, supporting the Department Manager and leadership team to drive outcomes aligned to Council’s values, culture, and priorities. What you will bring · Relevant qualification with several years of subsequent relevant experience OR lesser formal qualifications with extensive relevant experience · PROSCI certification or similar, and project management experience will be advantageous · Experience in communicating to an internal audience using a range of processes and tools · Experience leading large/complex organisational change initiatives will be an advantage · Ability to manage situations with internal stakeholders to resolve specialist problems and build long term relationships · Ability to motivate and facilitate teams and individuals from across the organisation and conduct consultations, take feedback and resolve issues If you progress past the interview stage, you may be required to complete pre-employment screening, which may include police checks, a medical, qualification verification, and an Australian work rights check. Why join Wyndham We are one of Australia’s fastest growing and most diverse cities. By 2040, we will have more than 500,000 residents and our people are hard at work designing the precincts, building the infrastructure, developing the policies and delivering the programs that will ensure the City is prepared. Look at our job opportunities and you may be surprised at what you discover: a future-focused culture, a sense of purpose and possibility, and real opportunities to strengthen our diverse community. It all adds up to make Wyndham City a great place to belong. Our people are our most valued asset. We are focused on building a culture that empowers every person to do their best work. Flexibility is built right into our DNA and we are committed to cultivating an inclusive workplace that celebrates a diverse workforce. How to apply Please apply online by submitting your resume and cover letter outlining your suitability for the role via the provided link. Applications close at 11:59PM on Sunday, 9 November 2025. If you have further role-specific questions, please contact Ryan Foote, Manager Facilities Fleet & Depot Stores on 8734 4544. Wyndham City Council is committed to providing a recruitment experience that is fair, inclusive, and accessible. If you have specific accessibility needs or general recruitment enquiries, please contact our Careers team via careers@wyndham.vic.gov.au or 03 9394 6860. Child Safe Organisation Wyndham City Council has zero tolerance to any form of child abuse and is committed to the safety, wellbeing and empowerment of children. We create and maintain a child safe organisation which is embedded in the everyday thinking and practice of all employees, volunteers and contractors. Additionally, we are committed to fostering a culture of safety within the Council, which includes the inclusion and empowerment of Aboriginal children, their families, and communities. Our recruitment practices reflect this. Diversity and Inclusion At Wyndham City Council we value workforce diversity and inclusion and embrace individual uniqueness. We value diverse life experiences and the perspectives of our people, while providing high-quality services to all members of our community, regardless of age, gender, ethnicity, religion, cultural background, disability, or sexuality. Wyndham has one of the largest Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities in the Western Region, with a rich and diverse history. item.title: Team Leader Early Education and Care Services (Bachelor Qualified)
item.salary: Salary determined by the EEEA 2020, with in charge allowance Location: Werribee based. This role may be required to work across multiple locations throughout the Wyndham Municipality About the role As Team Leader Education and Care Services, you will be responsible for the day-to-day operations and management of the kindergarten service and a team of educators by providing leadership and pedagogical support and guidance in line with family-centered practice. Reporting to the Area Leader Early Education and Care Services, you will be responsible for overseeing the implementation of planning and developing high quality programs for the service, while creating a team culture operating with a focus on continuous improvement. In addition to this, you will be required to participate in time spent in an educational capacity. You will be the face of the service as you engage with Council’s diverse community on different levels including building relationships with families, staff groups and the community. Engagement will be focussed on ensuring positive family and community participation in line with Council’s integrated service approach. To be eligible for this role you must have the following qualification and registration; Bachelor of Teaching (Early Childhood), Bachelor of Education (Early Childhood) or other relevant approved ACECQA qualification. Valid Victorian Institute of Teaching (VIT) registration What your day will look like Leading and supervising educators and volunteers at Wyndham’s kindergarten service. Proving guidance and support to parents and staff members through a diverse range of complex situations. Management of reporting and financial operation of the service reporting to senior leaders as regularly scheduled. Delivering insights and providing best practice knowledge around current trends in early years education, implementing this in line with the unit goals. Actively contributing to the success of Early Education and Care Services and the Community Life Directorate through teamwork and effective performance of the position responsibilities and duties. What you will bring Mandatory Qualifications to practice as an Early Childhood Teacher (ECT) in Victoria, as outlined in the Position Description: Bachelor of Teaching (Early Childhood), Bachelor of Education (Early Childhood) or other relevant approved ACECQA qualification. Valid Victorian Institute of Teaching (VIT) registration. In addition to the above qualifications: Experience in influence and providing direction to educators at the service, linking your problem solving, mentoring and confident decision-making skills. Extensive experience working in early years education, understanding the range of regulations and policies the service is governed by. Exceptional prioritisation and time management skills, to effectively navigate the duties of this busy role. Strong understanding of the variety of local, state and Commonwealth guidelines and regulations, and the ability to ensure compliance in line with council policies. Valid First Aid Certificate (including CPR) and related certifications as outlined in the position description. If you progress past the interview stage, you may be required to complete pre-employment screening, which may include police checks, a medical, qualification verification, and an Australian work rights check. Why join Wyndham We are one of Australia’s fastest growing and most diverse cities. By 2040, we will have more than 500,000 residents and our people are hard at work designing the precincts, building the infrastructure, developing the policies and delivering the programs that will ensure the City is prepared. Look at our job opportunities and you may be surprised at what you discover: a future-focused culture, a sense of purpose and possibility, and real opportunities to strengthen our diverse community. It all adds up to make Wyndham City a great place to belong. Our people are our most valued asset. We are focused on building a culture that empowers every person to do their best work. Flexibility is built right into our DNA and we are committed to cultivating an inclusive workplace that celebrates a diverse workforce. How to apply Please apply online by submitting your resume and cover letter outlining your suitability for the role via the provided link. Applications close at 11:59PM on Sunday 9 November 2025. If you have further role-specific questions, please contact Keith Burnell, Early Years Projects & Operations Lead on 03 8353 4033. Wyndham City Council is committed to providing a recruitment experience that is fair, inclusive, and accessible. If you have specific accessibility needs or general recruitment enquiries, please contact our Careers team via careers@wyndham.vic.gov.au or 03 9394 6860. Child Safe Organisation Wyndham City Council has zero tolerance to any form of child abuse and is committed to the safety, wellbeing and empowerment of children. Additionally, we are committed to fostering a culture of safety within the Council, which includes the inclusion and empowerment of Aboriginal children, their families, and communities. item.title: Community Care Worker
item.salary: Band 2 - Commencing at $66,631 pa Categories: Aged & Disability Support About the role As a part-time Community Care Worker, you will provide assistance to our Home Care Clients to maintain and improve their life, by providing of a range of direct practical assistance in their homes. Work type: Permanent Part-Time (15 - 25hrs per week) Classification: Band 2 $33.72 per hour + super Key responsibilities include: Perform general housework and cleaning Meal preparation Personal care tasks including personal grooming Provide support in maintaining social contacts, emotional health and well-being Monitor clients’ health and well-being and report any concerns. About you To be successful in this role, you will have experience providing personal care, domestic and household activities to people who are ageing, live with disability or mental illness. You will also: Hold a Certificate III in Individual Support (Aged) or equivalent Have a current First Aid Level 2, including CPR module Be willing to undergo a national police check, medical and functional assessments Have a current driver’s license, comprehensive insurance and a reliable registered motor vehicle Be physically able to carry out a range of household duties Have availability of 3 weekdays or greater Preferred candidates will be required to undergo a National Police Check and a Pre Employment Medical Assessment as part of the recruitment process. If this sounds like the role for you, then click apply now! Child Safety Responsibilities We are committed to being a child-safe organisation and have zero-tolerance for child abuse. We have specific policies, procedures, and mandatory training in place to support employees, volunteers, and contractors to achieve and adhere to these commitments. Please read our Child Safe Standards Management Policy . Diversity and Inclusion At the City we want a workforce that reflects the community we live in. We welcome and embrace everyone, all people with their own unique experiences, and support and encourage all our employees to do their best work, have equal access to opportunities and a just working environment. For this reason, we particularly welcome and encourage applications from First Nations people, people with diverse cultural and linguistic backgrounds, from the LGBTQIA+ community, people with disability and people of all genders, ages and diverse experience. We are the City From parks to offices, childcare centres to works depots, leisure facilities to the Wool Museum and waterfront, our team plays a vital role in shaping our vibrant and growing community. Our community counts on us to get the essentials right while looking for ways to go beyond. By listening, collaborating, and focusing on sustainability, we strive to do the basics brilliantly and create a lasting impact. If you’re ready to be part of something bigger, join us in shaping the future of Geelong. We support accessibility and encourage discussions about any adjustments or support you may need during the recruitment process. item.title: Lead Business Analyst
item.salary: SPL Categories: Information Technology About the role In this role, you’ll partner with key stakeholders, program teams, and business service owners to define, plan, and scope business and technology changes, ensuring seamless alignment between business needs and technology platforms. You’ll bring expert skills in business analysis, process design, and requirements management, collaborating across teams to drive the program’s strategic objectives and deliver lasting impact. Work type: 3 year fixed-term contract Classification: SPL Commencing at $148,599 + super Key responsibilities include: Deliver expert business analysis across multiple projects, applying best-practice frameworks to support systems and process improvements within the program. Capture, document, and manage clear functional and non-functional requirements, including well-defined acceptance criteria. Collaborate with stakeholders to translate user needs into precise, actionable user stories. Partner with process owners to analyze current workflows, uncover inefficiencies, and recommend improvements. Analyze integration needs by documenting business processes, system specifications, and data flows to guide solution design . Lead and enhance requirements management and traceability, ensuring alignment between requirements, design, development, and testing for quality and compliance. Facilitate and manage requirements workshops, fostering clear communication and collaboration to meet project and program goals. Serve as the key liaison between business leads, project managers, and system integrators to prioritize and align business needs with program objectives. About you To be successful in this role you will have a tertiary qualification in IT, Business, or similar fields with significant professional experience in a comparable organisation. Essential Experience: Significant Professional Experience in Business Analysis Demonstrated experience across large scale projects and programs in a comparable organisation. Practical experience with the use of business process methods e.g Lean, Six-Sigma. Working knowledge of Business Analysis Body of Knowledge (BABOK), Agile delivery, and Prince2 project management methodology Experience on high profile projects or programs with multiple enterprise wide integrated and inter-related systems Effective people leadership and teamwork skills to support an environment for high-functioning, productive and engaged teams to operate. Preferred candidates will be required to undergo a National Police Check and a Working With Children's Check as part of the recruitment process (funded by the City). If this sounds like the role for you, then click apply now! Child Safety Responsibilities We are committed to being a child-safe organisation and have zero-tolerance for child abuse. We have specific policies, procedures, and mandatory training in place to support employees, volunteers, and contractors to achieve and adhere to these commitments. For this reason, we particularly welcome and encourage applications from First Nations people, people with diverse cultural and linguistic backgrounds, from the LGBTQIA+ community, people with disability and people of all genders, ages and diverse experience. item.title: Technical Officer
item.salary: Band 5 - Commencing at $81,005 pa Categories: Engineering About the role In this role, you will support Engineers by ensuring that new developments meet Council requirements and standards. In addition, you’ll contribute to creating cutting-edge policies, plans, and practices to enhance our road and drainage infrastructure. This is an exciting opportunity to make a tangible impact on your community while helping to shape its future. Work type: Permanent full time Classification: Band 5 Commencing at $81,005 pa plus super Key responsibilities include: Assist with the evaluation of submitted engineering documentation including drawings and specifications relating to all private subdivisional development to confirm compliance with relevant Council standards and requirements. Assist with overseeing construction of approved subdivisional works in accordance with Council standards including monitoring of safe construction techniques and procedures. Liaise with developers, consultants, contractors, and statutory authorities and provide advice on Council standards and requirements. Liaise and direct activities of Council subdivision inspection personnel. Assist with monitor quality control of construction works. Ensure compliance with planning permit conditions including payment of required monies prior to release of titles for subdivisions. Provide engineering advice on matters such as traffic, drainage, car parking, etc for the issuing of development approvals. About you To be successful in this role, you will have a tertiary qualification in civil engineering, or substantial progress towards or relevant experience in a similar role. You will also have: Demonstrated ability to apply engineering principles in examining engineering documentation for subdivisional plans. Ability to communicate professionally, and concisely with staff and members of the community. Ability to set priorities and plan/organise work allocated. Ability to problem solve and think laterally to come up with innovative solutions to difficult problems. Current Victorian driver’s licence Preferred candidates will be required to undergo a National Police Check as part of the recruitment process (funded by the City). item.title: Expression of Interest – Swim, Sport & Leisure Casual Roles
item.salary: Band 2 Casual LSO - $43.05 p/h (inc casual loading) Categories: Leisure & Recreation We’re seeking enthusiastic, community-focused individuals to join our Swim, Sport & Leisure team. Whether you’re passionate about aquatic safety, teaching swimming, fitness, customer service, or sports coaching, we’d love to hear from you. This Expression of Interest (EOI) allows you to register your details for upcoming recruitment rounds. Submitting an EOI does not guarantee a role will be available ; however, it ensures we have your information on file when opportunities arise. All Swim, Sport & Leisure staff must hold a valid employee Working with Children Check (WWCC). Roles We Recruit For Lifeguard (Additional summer recruitment starts September) Ensure the safety and enjoyment of aquatic patrons Maintain high standards of pool supervision and safety compliance Essential: WWCC, CPR, First Aid, Lifeguard Qualification Learn to Swim Teacher Teach and assess swimming programs for all ages Engage positively with students and families Essential: WWCC, CPR, Swim Teacher License Customer Service Be the welcoming face of our centres Assist with memberships, bookings, and enquiries Essential: WWCC, CPR Gym Instructor Provide safe, effective gym instruction Screen, assess, and create personalised programs Deliver gym floor sessions Essential: WWCC, CPR, First Aid, Cert III (or higher) in Fitness Coaching / Referee Coach or officiate sports programs in a safe, inclusive environment Build participation and enjoyment for all skill levels Essential: WWCC, CPR, First Aid, Relevant Coaching Accreditation Locations Roles may be available at Bellarine Aquatic & Sports Centre, Norlane ARC, Leisurelink, Splashdown, Kardinia Aquatic Centre, Lara Aquatic Centre, North Bellarine Aquatic Centre, and Leisuretime Sports Precinct. If you’re passionate about recreation, safety, and community wellbeing, we’d love to receive your EOI. Please have your qualifications ready to upload. Child Safety We are a child-safe organisation with zero tolerance for child abuse. Policies, procedures, and training support all staff to uphold these commitments. Please review our Child Safe Standards Management Policy . Diversity & Inclusion We aim for a workforce that reflects our community and values diverse experiences. We ensure equal opportunity and encourage applications from First Nations peoples, culturally diverse communities, LGBTQIA+ individuals, people with disabilities, and people of all genders, ages, and experiences. About Us – We Are the City From parks to offices, leisure centres to waterfront attractions, our team shapes Geelong’s vibrant community. We deliver essentials brilliantly while striving for sustainability, collaboration, and long-term impact. We support accessibility and welcome discussions about adjustments during recruitment. Applications & Enquiries Position Description (Word) Position Description (PDF) Applications close: 11:55 pm, 1 August 2026 Enquiries: Talent Team

item.title: Senior People Partner
item.salary: Band 8 - Commencing at $122,040 pa Categories: Human Resources About the role During this 12-month, fixed term contract, you will provide trusted leadership across complex industrial and employee relations matters, ensuring positive and effective workplace outcomes in fast paced environment. With a strong focus on leadership effectiveness, organisational design and strategic people and culture initiatives, you’ll play a key role in driving outcomes that align with the City’s values and long-term strategic direction. Work type: 12 month fixed-term contract Classification: Band 8, $122,040 pa plus super Key responsibilities include: Provide expert industrial relations, employee relations, and strategic people advice to stakeholders, ensuring alignment with the Business Plan, City objectives, legislation, and policy requirements. Partner strategically with Executive Directors and Senior Leaders to deliver expert guidance across all areas of people, culture, and organisational effectiveness. Offer high-level advice and solutions on complex workforce challenges, including organisational design and change, industrial and employee relations, workforce planning, performance, and talent management. Conduct in-depth research and analysis on industrial, employee relations, and broader people matters to deliver practical, evidence-based solutions that drive positive outcomes for key stakeholders. Champion innovation and continuous improvement within the department, fostering a culture that embraces best practice and delivers exceptional outcomes for both customers and the community. Monitor, report, and utilise accurate data to track work progress and improvements against plans and budgets. Implement systems, processes, and workflows to deliver results, ensuring relevant policies, governance mechanisms, and regulations are adhered to. About you To be successful in this role, you will have a tertiary qualification in relevant Human Resources/ Industrial Relations and or significant professional experience in Human Resources/ Industrial Relations in a comparable organisation. Essential Experience: In-depth knowledge of relevant legislation, policies, and best practices relating to Human Resources and Industrial Relations. Proven ability to build relationships, influence, and collaborate effectively with a diverse range of stakeholders. Demonstrated understanding and application of a contemporary Business Partnering model, supporting activities such as coaching, workforce planning, and change management. Exempary written, verbal, and presentation skills, with the ability to engage stakeholders and gain support for key initiatives. Strong problem-solving and stakeholder management skills, with a focus on fostering collaboration and productive partnerships. Experience in designing and implementing HR strategies that meet both strategic and operational organisational needs. Proven ability to work independently, analyse complex and sometimes conflicting information, and deliver effective, evidence-based solutions. Competent at managing competing priorities and achieving results in a fast-paced, politically aware, and dynamic environment. Preferred candidates will be required to undergo a National Police Check and a Working with Children's Check as part of the recruitment process (funded by the City). If this sounds like the role for you, then click apply now! Child Safety Responsibilities We are committed to being a child-safe organisation and have zero-tolerance for child abuse. We have specific policies, procedures, and mandatory training in place to support employees, volunteers, and contractors to achieve and adhere to these commitments. item.title: Kitchen Hand
item.salary: Band 1 - Commencing at $64,217 pa Categories: Early Childhood Education About the role Based at our Boorai Child and Family Centre (Ocean Grove), you will be responsible for assisting in the preparation of age-appropriate meals and snacks in accordance with current food safety legislation and nutritional guidelines. You will also maintain the kitchen environment and equipment in a safe and hygienic manner at all times. Work type: Permanent Part-Time (3 hrs per day, Monday - Friday) Classification: Band 1 $32.49 per hour Key responsibilities include: Assist with the preparation and serving of meals appropriate to a variety of age groups. Maintain the cleanliness and hygiene of the kitchen in accordance with Health and Safety Regulations Maintain communication with Centre staff and parents in relation to the individual dietary requirements of children. About you To be successful in this role, you will have knowledge of preschool children’s nutritional requirements and food safety, and the ability to assist in the preparation of age-appropriate meals for a large number of children. Essential: A current Working with Children Check Ability to identify Health and Safety issues in the work environment. Ability to assist in the preparation of nutritionally balanced and age-appropriate meals for a large number of young children incorporating meals for children with specific dietary requirements. item.title: Program Coordinator
item.salary: Band 8 - Commencing at $122,040 pa Categories: Information Technology About the role As Program Coordinator, you’ll work across teams to ensure smooth delivery of the City’s key digital transformation program, Asset and Customer Enablement (ACE) program, providing expert advice, planning, and analysis. You’ll manage resources, timelines, and budgets to keep everything aligned and on target, ensuring key outcomes are achieved. Work type: 3 year fixed-term contract Classification: Band 8, $122.040 + super Key responsibilities include: Overseeing the day-to-day operation of the program, ensuring operations are executed according to plan. Coordinate and support team efforts to ensure timely delivery of program outcomes, proactively identifying ways to keep work on track. Build strong cross-functional partnerships with project managers, stakeholders, and technical and business teams to maintain alignment and drive successful delivery. Facilitate all aspects of the program’s resources, financials, schedules, and integrated planning for effective operations; regularly tracking and reporting on performance. Monitor and track budgets, benefits, contracts, resources, and services, ensuring expenditure within allocated budgets. Manage all key administrative processes across the program, including scheduling meetings, developing meeting agendas, tracking actions, decisions and outcomes. Develop and maintain accurate documents, co-ordinate and perform various analysis, insights and presentations to track progress, inform decision making and enable effective program governance. Identify and address potential program issues & risks proactively, taking the initiative to ensure success. Maintain relationships with a diverse set of internal and external stakeholders by adapting communication content and style to meet their needs. Provide subject matter expertise and advice to leaders and other relevant stakeholders. About you To be successful in this role, you will have a tertiary qualification in Information Technology, Computer Science or Business Management in addition to professional experience in project management or project coordination. Essential Experience: Proven ability to lead and support teams, fostering a collaborative and high-performing work environment. Strong written, verbal, and negotiation skills to influence stakeholders and gain buy-in for key initiatives. Effective problem-solving and relationship-building skills, with the ability to create strong partnerships across stakeholders. Skilled in data analysis and reporting, with the ability to interpret insights and clearly communicate findings. Experienced in driving and supporting change, ensuring proactive stakeholder engagement throughout transitions. Demonstrated expertise in financial administration, including budgeting, forecasting, and contract management. Strong stakeholder engagement skills, with a track record of working collaboratively across internal teams. Preferred candidates will be required to undergo a National Police Check Check and a Working with Children’s Check as part of the recruitment process (funded by the City). item.title: Fire Prevention Officer
item.salary: Band 5 - Commencing at $81,005 pa Categories: Local Laws, Compliance & Regulation About the role In this role, you will contribute to the efficient and effective operation of Council’s processes and responsibilities for fire hazard identification and compliance with Council’s Local Law, Country Fire Authority (CFA) Act 1958 and Fire Rescue Victoria (FRV) Act 1958. Work type: Fixed Term (3 months) – Full Time Classification: Band 5 Commencing at $40.99 per hour Key responsibilities include: Community Engagement & Compliance : Liaise with the public regarding fire prevention, respond to complaints and enquiries, and promote compliance with relevant legislation, local laws, and council policies. Fire Hazard Inspections & Enforcement : Conduct annual fire hazard inspections, oversee seasonal staff, issue notices, and prepare documentation for legal proceedings if necessary. Planning & Reporting : Support the planning and review of the Municipal Fire Management Plan and Victorian Fire Risk Register and contribute to seasonal planning and end-of-season evaluations. Training & Support : Assist with the induction and mentoring of seasonal employees and help develop efficient record-keeping systems using council software. Administrative & Legal Duties : Write reports, maintain accurate records, represent the City in court when required, and make decisions on fire prevention notices and compliance actions. About you To be successful in this role, you will have strong communication skills with the ability to liaise with members of the community in relation to problem solving and negotiation. You must be able to work within a small but highly motivated team and enjoy putting ideas and suggestions across in line with our Better Ways of Working. Essential Experience: Completion of the Municipal Fire Prevention Officer Course an advantage but not essential. Completion of Maintain Safety at Fire Incident training an advantage but not essential. A current Victorian Driver's Licence and Working with Children’s Check You will gain knowledge of Fire Management Planning and experience in emergency management. If this sounds like the role for you, then click apply now! Child Safety Responsibilities We are committed to being a child-safe organisation and have zero-tolerance for child abuse. item.salary: Band 6 - Commencing at $95,760 pa Categories: Engineering About the role In this role, you will assist, supervise, prepare and implement sustainable traffic strategies, programs and works to facilitate the efficient movement of people and product throughout having regard to economic, social and environmental values. Deliver an excellent customer experience in relation to matters concerning the City’s transport and traffic management, including the resolution of complex customer enquiries and concerns relating to the role. item.title: Plant, Heavy Fleet Management and In Vehicle Monitoring Officer
item.salary: Band 6 - Commencing at $95,760 pa Categories: Local Laws, Compliance & Regulation, Trades & Labour About the role Play a key role in managing and optimising the City of Greater Geelong’s fleet and plant assets. In this diverse and hands-on position, you’ll support the strategic planning, procurement, and replacement of vehicles and equipment to ensure they are safe, cost-effective, and fit for purpose. You’ll assist in delivering the Ten-Year Plant Replacement Program, guide procurement activities, and drive improvements in asset utilisation, safety, and operational efficiency through effective use of In-Vehicle Management Systems (IVMS). Your work will help ensure our fleet supports essential community services and aligns with Council’s sustainability and service delivery goals. This role offers the opportunity to collaborate across departments, contribute to continuous improvement, and make a tangible impact on how we deliver services to the Geelong community. Work type: Permanent Full Time Classification: Band 6 Commencing at $95,760 pa plus super Key responsibilities include: Fleet and Asset Management – Support the effective management, utilisation, and recordkeeping of Council’s fleet and plant assets, ensuring vehicles and equipment are safe, fit for purpose, and cost-effective. Procurement and Planning – Assist in developing and implementing the Ten-Year Plant Replacement Program and coordinate fleet procurement, replacement, and disposal activities in line with Council procedures and budgets. In-Vehicle Management Systems (IVMS) – Oversee the operation, compliance, and data integrity of IVMS, analysing data to enhance safety, operational planning, and asset utilisation. Policy, Compliance and Improvement – Contribute to the development and review of fleet policies and procedures, ensuring alignment with legislation, best practice, and continuous improvement objectives. Training and Stakeholder Support – Deliver operator training and familiarisation sessions, provide subject matter advice, and build positive relationships with internal stakeholders and external agencies. Team and Service Excellence – Support a collaborative, customer-focused team culture and contribute to a commercially driven, innovative approach to fleet management and service delivery. About you You’re a skilled and organised professional with experience in fleet management, plant operations, or vehicle maintenance. You bring a practical mindset, strong stakeholder skills, and a commitment to safety and innovation. You’ll enjoy working in a collaborative team that values professionalism, continuous improvement, and service excellence. Essential Experience: Relevant qualification in Vehicle Mechanics and or significant professional experience in specialist field(s) in a comparable organisation. Good problem solving and stakeholder management skills to work effectively with diverse stakeholders to achieve task outcomes. Demonstrated experience in fleet asset procurement and disposal aligned with current best practice, including financial planning and budget management. Substantial experience administering a diverse fleet using asset and maintenance management systems. Victorian Drivers Licence Preferred candidates will be required to undergo a National Police Check as part of the recruitment process (funded by the City). If this sounds like the role for you, then click apply now! Child Safety Responsibilities We are committed to being a child-safe organisation and have zero-tolerance for child abuse. We have specific policies, procedures, and mandatory training in place to support employees, volunteers, and contractors to achieve and adhere to these commitments. Please read our Child Safe Standards Management Policy . Diversity and Inclusion At the City we want a workforce that reflects the community we live in. We welcome and embrace everyone, all people with their own unique experiences, and support and encourage all our employees to do their best work, have equal access to opportunities and a just working environment. For this reason, we particularly welcome and encourage applications from First Nations people, people with diverse cultural and linguistic backgrounds, from the LGBTQIA+ community, people with disability and people of all genders, ages and diverse experience. We are the City From parks to offices, childcare centres to works depots, leisure facilities to the Wool Museum and waterfront, our team plays a vital role in shaping our vibrant and growing community. item.title: Senior IT Project Manager
item.salary: SPL Categories: Information Technology About the role In this role, you will oversee every stage of the systems development life cycle, ensuring projects are delivered on time, within budget, and to the highest quality standards. Your expertise in managing resources, schedules, budgets, and stakeholders will be key to achieving our ambitious goals. Work type: 3 year fixed term contract Classification: SPL, Commencing at $ $148,599 + plus super Key responsibilities include: Lead and manage the planning, delivery and closure of ICT projects within the ACE Program. Offer guidance and support to the project team, communicate the project vision and outcomes and support the team in achieving the project outcomes in a timely manner. Provide indirect leadership across cross-functional teams, fostering collaboration, accountability, and alignment with ACE program priorities. Steer the planning and delivery of wide range of information gathering and stakeholder consultation to specify, negotiate and agree on project deliverables Support the project governance and delivery of projects using the standard tools and templates and ensure intended outcomes are identified and achieved. Identify, assess, and manage project risks, issues, dependencies, and constraints, developing mitigation strategies and escalating critical matters to the Program Manager and Sponsor as required. Prepare project review reports, dashboards, and presentations to support governance reviews, performance tracking, and benefits realization. Continuously evaluate and enhance project management processes, identifying opportunities for improvement to strengthen delivery efficiency and team performance. Effectively manage project resources, including forecasting, allocation, and oversight of budgets and costs to ensure financial accuracy and accountability. About you To be successful in this role, you will have a tertiary qualification in Information Technology, Computer Science or Business Management. In addition, you will have a relevant professional project management certification (Prince2 or equivalent). Essential Experience: Proven experience in project delivery, with a strong record of successfully managing and delivering complex business and ICT projects. In-depth knowledge of enterprise systems, including hands-on experience implementing or working with modern ERP platforms (e.g., CRM, Asset Management) or similar large-scale business systems. Exceptional communication skills, with the ability to clearly and confidently present complex information to diverse audiences, both verbally and in writing. Strong adaptability and resilience, with the ability to navigate ambiguity and manage complex or evolving situations effectively. Advanced analytical and problem-solving capabilities within ICT environments, particularly when working with challenging or high-stakes stakeholder groups. Proven stakeholder engagement skills, with the ability to build productive partnerships and influence at all organisational levels to achieve successful outcomes. Demonstrated leadership ability, fostering a collaborative, high-performing, and engaged project team environment. Comprehensive knowledge of project management methodologies, including Waterfall, Agile/Scrum, or hybrid models, coupled with a solid understanding of change management principles and practices. Preferred candidates will be required to undergo a National Police Check and a Working with Children’s Check as part of the recruitment process (funded by the City). item.title: Senior Team Leader – Unsealed Roads
item.salary: Band 4 - Commencing at $73,796 pa Categories: Trades & Labour About the role In this role, you will lead and coordinate the Unsealed Roads crew to deliver high-quality road and footpath maintenance across multiple sites. Reporting to the Works Supervisor, you will provide on-site leadership, ensure safety and efficiency, and support your team to achieve maximum productivity. Work type: Permanent Full Time. Classification: Band 4 Commencing at $73,796 pa plus super Key responsibilities include: Supervise and provide direction to team members, plant operators, and contractors on-site. Coordinate daily maintenance operations, including the efficient use of plant, materials, and equipment. Record and report daily outputs, repairs, and works completed. Operate and maintain plant and equipment safely and effectively. Ensure all worksites comply with Council health and safety policies and traffic management requirements. Contribute to team and operational improvements while delivering excellent customer service to internal and external stakeholders. About you To be successful in this role, you are a hands-on leader with experience in unsealed road maintenance, plant operation, and traffic management. You thrive in a fast-paced, outdoor environment, providing clear direction to your team while ensuring safety, productivity, and high-quality outcomes. Strong organisational and communication skills, integrity, and a commitment to excellent service define how you work. Essential Experience: Current Victorian Drivers licence and Current Victorian Medium Rigid licence. Accreditation in: Basic worksite traffic management and Traffic controlling (stop/slow bat) and previous experience in working with excavating machinery. Demonstrated ability to play a leading role in the supervision and direction of maintenance works being performed by the team. Ability to order and estimate quantities. Ability to operate various items of plant and equipment. Ability to perform manual work including lifting of weights in accordance with Occupational Health and Safety guidelines. item.title: Senior Heritage Officer
item.salary: Band 7 - Commencing at $106,158 pa Categories: Urban Design & Planning About the role In this role, you’ll provide expert advice on built heritage referrals from internal and external stakeholders, and strengthen the City’s relationship with State government partners. You’ll also lead the implementation of heritage studies and offer sound advice and leadership to Council on all matters relating to heritage and conservation. Work type: Permanent, part-time position. 3 days a week. Classification: Band 7, $106,158 pa plus super pro rata Key responsibilities include: Deliver timely, high-quality responses to internal and external stakeholders, ensuring built heritage needs and standards are met. Interpret and advise on legislative, regulatory, and policy requirements to guide referrals, overlays, and Council reports. Analyse proposals and offer technical heritage input into assessments and key City projects. Prepare heritage assessments and oversee external heritage consultants where required. Support the Coordinator Built Heritage in delivering the City’s Heritage Strategy and developing policies and plans that protect and celebrate Geelong’s heritage assets. Work with internal teams, consultants, community groups, and government agencies to achieve best-practice heritage outcomes. Provide trusted, specialist advice on heritage buildings and places to leaders and stakeholders across Council. Work with the Coordinator to implement the Built Heritage Unit’s annual plans and strategic goals in line with corporate priorities. Track progress and report on outcomes to ensure projects, referrals, and strategies are delivered on time, on budget, and to the highest standards. About you To be successful in this role you will have a tertiary qualification in heritage, collection management, architecture, planning or related field and significant professional experience in heritage or collection management in a comparable organisation. Essential Experience: Proven experience preparing heritage and built form policies, studies, conservation management plans, statements of significance, and referral advice. Demonstrated ability to deliver built heritage strategies, policies, or projects on time and to a high standard. Skilled at managing multiple tasks and competing priorities while maintaining quality outcomes. Strong ability to resolve issues, build partnerships, and foster cooperation across diverse stakeholders. Experience contributing to a positive, inclusive, and multidisciplinary team environment. Proven ability to work with community groups, government agencies, and other stakeholders to achieve heritage outcomes aligned with Council objectives and policies. Preferred candidates will be required to undergo a National Police Check as part of the recruitment process (funded by the City). If this sounds like the role for you, then click apply now! item.title: Senior Change Lead
item.salary: SPL Categories: Business Strategy & Improvement About the role In this role, you will effectively plan and manage change activities within your portfolio of work, operating to and applying a consistent approach to change management, standards of accreditation and skill across projects at the City. You will play a critical role in building and maturing the change management capability at the City. Work type: 12 month fixed-term contract. Classification: SPL 148,599 pa + super. Key responsibilities include: Lead the planning and execution of change management activities to support implementation of strategic initiatives across the organisation Develop, integrate and implement contemporary and best practice change management strategies & plans to identify and respond to change impacts, build change resilience and optimise business readiness. Work collaboratively with project teams, People & Culture team, leaders, and change champions to socialise, integrate and embed changes. Provide subject matter or expert advice to the Directorate, ELT and other leaders across the organisation. Plan, develop and implement targeted communication and engagement strategies to ensure all stakeholders are informed, understand and embrace the change. Prepare reports, briefings and presentations to support and influence stakeholders to achieve project objectives and provide successful transition for teams and individuals Lead and manage key change training deliverables including training needs analysis, training planning and the design and development of training activities in line with adult learning principles to enable the successful implementation of change initiatives. Design, implement and manage change management processes in a unionized environment with close consideration on the industrial obligations set out in the Enterprise Agreement and associated complexities. Motivate and provide strong operational leadership to the team by fostering an inclusive, customer focused and accountable culture. About you To be successful in this role, you will have a tertiary qualification in Human Resources, Commerce/Business, Organisation Psychology or a similar field and significant professional experience in a senior change management position in a comparable organisation. Essential Experience: Demonstrated leadership and people management experience. Well-developed problem solving and stakeholder management skills with the ability to build cooperation and partnerships. Demonstrated experience in developing and delivering change management, communication, and engagement strategies within large-scale and complex project/program environments. Knowledge of contemporary, best practice change management, change communication and stakeholder engagement frameworks and methodologies. Demonstrated ability to work in partnership with the business and project teams to deliver informed, tailored and strategic change and communication products Preferred candidates will be required to undergo a National Police Check and a Working with Children's Check as part of the recruitment process (funded by the City). If this sounds like the role for you, then click apply now! Child Safety Responsibilities We are committed to being a child-safe organisation and have zero-tolerance for child abuse. item.title: Qualified Gardener
item.salary: Band 3 - Commencing at $68,775 pa Categories: Trades & Labour About the role In this role, you will carry out horticultural and maintenance tasks, operate and maintain equipment safely, and support the Parks team in delivering high-quality, customer-focused services. You will also engage with the community and ensure accurate records of work are maintained. Work type: Permanent full time Classification: Band 2 commencing at $66,631 pa plus super (unqualified). Band 3 commencing at $68,775 pa plus super (qualified). Key responsibilities include: Follow all reasonable directions given by the Team Leader and other more senior staff in accordance with operational requirements which may include, but is not limited to, weeding, mowing, propagation, spraying of appropriate insecticides, herbicides and fungicides to a regular or modified program as required. Undertake tasks including site preparation, planting, maintenance, and liaising with community groups and the public. Operate and maintain plant and equipment, which may include, but is not limited to, sprayers, hand/small ride on mowers, small tractors and related machinery, in an effective and efficient manner and in compliance with relevant laws/regulations, codes of practice and applicable directives. Work within all Council health and safety policies and procedures. Effective and efficient recording of maintenance works undertaken, time sheets, plant sheets and recorded on Councils Management Maintenance system. About you To be successful in this role, you will have a Certificate III in Horticulture / Certificate III in Parks and Gardens or similar, or a genuine passion for horticultural maintenance in the parks environment with the commitment to undertake funded training to gain your qualification. Essential Experience: Experience in a range of horticultural activities preferably in a maintenance role. Good knowledge of a range of plant material including their growing conditions and maintenance requirements and ability to further develop knowledge through research and practical observation. Extensive experience in the broad range of horticultural maintenance activities performed in the Parks environment. Ability to embrace technology and new ways of working. Current Working with Children check (employee) A current Victorian medium truck licence (desirable). item.title: Organisation Planning and Insights Analyst
item.salary: Band 7 - Commencing at $106,158 pa Categories: Governance & Legal About the role The Organisation Planning and Insights Analyst plays a key role in shaping how the City plans, measures, and improves its performance. This position is responsible for developing and driving the City’s corporate and service planning frameworks, organisational performance measurement and reporting processes, and continuous review programs. You will evaluate service performance and community needs through financial, operational, and benchmarking analysis to assess efficiency, effectiveness, and strategic alignment. Work type: Permanent, full-time. Classification: Band 7, $ 106158, pa plus super Key responsibilities include: Partner with teams across the organisation to lead and support the Annual Business Planning Cycle, ensuring responsibilities are clearly defined and cascaded through the Accountability Framework. Collaborate proactively with senior leaders and their teams to identify opportunities for continuous improvement, embedding robust planning practices into everyday operations. Coordinate strategic discussions and planning activities with internal and external stakeholders to ensure alignment, informed decision-making, and effective delivery of organisational goals. Drive the end-to-end delivery of service reviews, ensuring consistency, transparency, and compliance with the Local Government Act 2020 and other regulatory standards. Evaluate service performance and community needs through financial, operational, and benchmarking analysis to assess efficiency, effectiveness, and strategic alignment. Deliver actionable, evidence-based recommendations and partner with stakeholders to embed outcomes into business planning, service planning, and budgeting processes. About you To be successful in this role, you will have a tertiary qualification in Commerce or Business fields or significant professional experience in Commerce or Business fields in a comparable organisation. Essential Experience: Understanding of evaluation methodologies / frameworks. Demonstrated experience working through milestones and stage gates. Proven ability to analyse information and make judgments. Strong interpersonal skills with the ability to engage, influence, and collaborate effectively with a wide range of stakeholders. Adept at using digital tools and technology to deliver compelling, persuasive presentations. Thrives working autonomously under broad direction, consistently delivering outcomes aligned to strategic goals and KPIs. For this reason, we particularly welcome and encourage applications from First Nations people, people with diverse cultural and linguistic backgrounds, from the LGBTQIA+ community, people with disability and people of all genders, ages and diverse experience. We are the City From parks to offices, childcare centres to works depots, leisure facilities to the Wool Museum and waterfront, our team plays a vital role in shaping our vibrant and growing community. Our community counts on us to get the essentials right while looking for ways to go beyond. By listening, collaborating, and focusing on sustainability, we strive to do the basics brilliantly and create a lasting impact. If you’re ready to be part of something bigger, join us in shaping the future of Geelong. We support accessibility and encourage discussions about any adjustments or support you may need during the recruitment process. Applications and Enquiries Click the Position Description link to view more information about this position. Enquiries: Alex Stebbing

item.title: The Role
item.description:
Nurse Immunisers

Horsham, Australia

Reference: 6807311

Casual Engagement (open-ended application arrangements)

An opportunity for suitably qualified individuals to join the HRCC immunisation team is available.

Nurse immunisers play a crucial role in protecting our community, by delivering the National Immunisation Program.

The successful applicants will be Registered Nurses with a Nurse Immuniser qualification. Ability to work off site and a Working with Children Check is required.

For a confidential conversation, please contact Coordinator Youth & Early Yers, Louise Kelly on 5382 9522

For more information, please see attached Position Description.

Applications will be received on an open-ended basis and interviews may proceed at any time.

Applications Close: 31 Dec 2025

item.title: Current vacancies
item.description:
• Home
  • Council
  • Careers

Current vacancies

    General Counsel

    Apply now Job no: 493460
    Work type: Permanent
    Location: Melbourne
    Categories: Compliance

    General Counsel

    Build a practical in-house legal function for our future

    Mitchell Shire is entering a defining chapter.

    40km north of Melbourne, our Shire spans Beveridge, Wallan, Kilmore, Broadford and Seymour. We’re a key growth corridor — balancing rapid residential expansion with the country character and community values that make Mitchell, Mitchell. With more than 64,000 residents today and strong growth ahead, every one of our 40+ townships has a role to play.

    We’re setting the organisation up for what’s next.

    A new structure, four new senior leadership roles, clearer accountability and faster decisions. This position — our first in-house General Counsel — brings Legal and Property together to enable timely, well-reasoned decisions, reduce external spend and protect public value. It’s strategic when required and hands-on when it counts.

    About the role

    The General Counsel is Council’s principal legal adviser.

    Reporting to the Director, Organisational Performance and working with the Senior Management Team, you’ll establish a contemporary, service-oriented legal function, lead the Property team and turn complexity into clear, actionable solutions.  

    Focus areas include property transactions, commercial agreements, procurement and probity, governance and administrative decision-making - supported by the systems and templates that help teams deliver at pace.

    Your focus is simple: help the organisation make good decisions, quickly and confidently.

    You’ll deliver:

    • Clear, plain-language advice across property, contracts, procurement, planning, governance and administrative law.
    • Drafting and negotiation of leases, licences, deeds and commercial agreements aligned to Council’s risk profile and obligations.
    • Practical te

• Home
  • Council
  • Careers
  • Current vacancies

Current vacancies

    Swim Instructor

    Apply now Job no: 493202
    Work type: Casual
    Location: Melbourne
    Categories: Leisure Services

    Swim Instructors 

    Mitchell Shire Council has embarked on Victoria’s last great story of growth.

    Located just 40 minutes from Melbourne where the city meets the country, we’re renowned for our scenic beauty that’s rich in both history and heritage.  We’re home to a mix of beautiful natural landscapes, townships and emerging communities in some of Australia’s fastest-growing suburbs.

    Come join a Local Government Organisation offering a fantastic opportunity for Community, Opportunity and Growth for the right applicant.

    This is your opportunity to join a supportive organisation in an area with rapid population growth. In 2025 Mitchell Shire is home to 64,175 residents, it is forecast to grow to 221,636 by 2046.

    About the Role

    A typical day in the role includes educating a range of age groups on water safety by the development of fun and engagement programs, supporting the provision of a safe environment for patrons, ensuring that the Aquatic Facilities operates in a clean, hygienic and safe manner in accordance with health regulations and public safety requirements. Our Leisure Centres operate seven (7) days a week with outdoor pools running through the Summer Season.

    This is a casual opportunity with the hourly rate beginning at $42.57 (LSO Band 3) plus superannuation. Positions are available at both Seymour and Kilmore Leisure Centres.

    About you

    You will be energetic, passionate and fun. You work well within a team, have outstanding communication skills and enjoy dealing with the public. You take initiative and are professional in your approach. You will possess a current level 2 first aid (HLTAID003, current Employee Working with Children Check and current AUSTSWIM or similar accreditation.

    If you are passionate about providing exceptional customer service and value water safety, this is a great oppo
